antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

changeHistory:
Version	4.37	Publication Date: 10/18/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose Series -> Select Patient Series -> Minimum Age To Start	18 years	2 years	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.
Change	2	1-dose Series -> Indication -> Text Description	Administer to adult travelers (aged 18-64 years) from the United States traveling to an area of active cholera transmission.	Administer to travelers from the United States traveling to an area of active cholera transmission.	Removed age portion of the text description.
Change	3	1-dose Series -> Indication -> Begin Age	18 years	2 years	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.
Change	4	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> Age	18 years - 4 days | 18 years | 18 years	2 years - 4 days | 2 years | 2 years	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.
Change	5	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> Preferable Vaccine -> Begin Age	18 years	6 years	Lowered 100 mL usage of this vaccine down to 6 years per package insert and ACIP recommended usage.
Change	6	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Vaccine	n/a	Duplciate CVX 174 entry for those between 2 years and 6 years of age.	Created a duplicate CVX 174 for those between the ages of 2 years and 6 years where only 50 mL should be used.
Change	7	1-dose Series -> Dose 1 -> Allowable Vaccine -> Begin Age	18 years	2 years - 4 days	Lowered begin age due to new ACIP recommendations.

Version	4.17
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose series -> Dose 1 -> Preferable Interval -> Heading	From Previous Dose Administered? Y/N	From Immediate Previous Dose Administered? Y/N	There was a typo in the heading for the interval that needed to be changed to be consistent. The word "immediate" was missing. No functional change in Cholera recommendations or Supporting Data.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Minimum Age To Start and Maximum Age To Start	N/A	18 years and 65 years respectively	Minimum Age To Start and Maximum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age and latest Indication End Age

Administrative Guidance	The Vaxchora package insert states that CVD 103-HgR should not be given to patients who have received oral or parenteral antibiotics in the preceding 14 days, because antibiotics might have activity against the vaccine strain. 
Administrative Guidance	Non-U.S. vaccines (WC-rBS and BivWC) would count as valid only if there is documentation that a complete series with the appropriate dosing has been given.
Administrative Guidance	No data exist on use of the currently available lyophilized CVD 103-HgR formulation in immunocompromised populations.

SERIES GROUP 1 | STANDARD

Start at 6 mo - 4 yrs Pfizer	Pfizer specific primary series for those who receive their first dose on or after 6 months of age through 4 years of life. Additional doses after the primary seris may or may not be Pfizer

Start at 6 mo - 4 yrs Moderna	Moderna specific primary series for those who receive their first dose on or after 6 months of age through 4 years of life. Additional doses after the primary series may or may not be Moderna.

Start at 5 yrs+ Series	Series for those who receive their first dose on or after 5 years of age

12 yrs+ Novavax Series	Series for those who have never been vaccinated and opt for the 2023-2024 Novavax product

Start at 6 mo - 4 yrs Mixed Product	Series for those who receive their first dose on or after 6 months through 4 years of age and received mixed products for the primary series.

Novavax Early Start Series	Series for those who are between the ages of 5 year through 11 years of age and received a Novavax 2023-24 vaccine as their very first COVID vaccine.

Novavax Off Label Series	Evaluation Only series in the event a patient received 2 Novavax doses with one or both coming under 12 years of age.

SERIES GROUP 2 | RISK

Risk IC 6 mo - 4yrs Pfizer Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for Pfizer COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients who begin vaccination under 5 years of age

Risk IC 5 yrs+ Pfizer Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for Pfizer COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients who begin vaccination on or after 5 years of age

Risk IC 6 mo+ Moderna Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients

Risk IC 18 yrs+ Janssen Series	Risk 1-dose series plus booster(s) for Janssen COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients

Risk IC 12 yrs+ Novavax Series	Risk 2-dose series plus booster

Risk IC 6 mo+ Mixed Product Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for mRNA COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients who begin vaccination under 5 years of age

Risk IC 6 mo+ Mixed Product Series	Risk 3-dose series plus booster(s) for mRNA COVID-19 Vaccine for Immunocompromised patients who begin vaccination on or after 5 years of age

Risk IC WHO-Authorized Series	Includes all WHO-Authorized vaccines and Emergency Use Instructions (EUI) for series completion and booster(s) for persons who are at increased risk.

Risk IC Medicago Clinical Trial Series	2-dose series for Medicago Clinical Trial vaccine including Emergency Use Instructions (EUI) for booster(s).
changeHistory:
Version	4.54	Publication Date: 03/08/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Start at 5 years+ -> New Dose	n/a	Added a new Dose #1	This supports an edge case gap that was discovered during testing when only Novavax was administered. It was possible for this series to be selected rather than the Novavax-specific series. Dose 1 does not include the 2023/2024 Novavax (CVX 313) as a preferable or allowable vaccine. 
Change	2	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose renumbering	Dose 1	Dose 2	Previous Dose #1 is now Dose #2
Change	3	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose 2 -> Preferable Interval -> From Most Recent CVX -> Cessation Date	n/a	45350	This cessation date retires this interval. The new 65+ recommendations move the additional dose recommendations spacing out to 4 months from previous 2023/2024 COVID vaccines. See next change for the new interval.
Change	4	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose 2 -> Preferable Interval -> From Most Recent CVX -> New interval	n/a	New interval of 4 months from previous 2023/2024 dose	The new 65+ recommendations move the additional dose recommendations spacing out to 4 months from previous 2023/2024 COVID vaccines.
Change	5	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose 2 -> Added conditions to existing skip	Target Dose is not needed after one dose has been administered on or after 9/12/2023	Target Dose is not needed after one dose has been administered on or after 9/12/2023 AND patient is under 65 years of age	Added a condition to only skip this dose if the patient is under 65 years old. See next change log for skipping when patient is 65 years of age or older.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	6 mo - 4 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 4 -> New Preferable Vaccines	308, 309, 310	Added CVX 311, 312	Persons under 5 years of age should be recommended Pfizer (homologous recommendation). However, if that person has aged to 5 years or over, they can be recommended Pfizer or Moderna (heterologous recommendation).
Change	2	6 mo - 4 yrs Moderna -> Dose 3 -> New Preferable Vaccines	311, 312	Added CVX 309, 310	Persons under 5 years of age should be recommended Pfizer (homologous recommendation). However, if that person has aged to 5 years or over, they can be recommended Pfizer or Moderna (heterologous recommendation). CVX 308 (Pfizer) was not added as this should not be recommended for those who received Moderna primary series and are still between the ages of 6 months and 5 years of age.
Change	3	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New Preferable Interval from most recent CVX	Added intentional spacing of 8 weeks for the new class of 2023-2024 fall vaccines. This is helpful to ensure those who started under 5 years of age stay on those under 5 series. 
Change	4	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose 1 -> Removed Allowable Vaccine	CVX 219, 302 present	removed CVX 219, 302	CVX 219, and 302 would not be an allowable usage in a patient who began vaccination on/after 5 years of age. This has been removed as an allowable and added as an inadvertent (see next change).
Change	5	Start at 5 years+ -> Dose 1 -> New Inadvertent Vaccine	308	Added CVX 219, 302	CVX 219 and 302 would not be an allowable usage in a patient who began vaccination on/after 5 years of age. Added as an inadvertent vaccine.
Change	6	6 mo - 4 yrs Mixed Product -> Dose 3 -> Allowable Vaccine 228 -> End Age	n/a	7 years	This product (CVX 228) should have an upper limit. This was set to 7 years to be consistent with other doses and series where this is allowable.
Change	7	Risk IC 6 mo - 4 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 4 -> New Preferable Vaccines	308, 309, 310	Added CVX 311, 312	Persons under 5 years of age should be recommended Pfizer (homologous recommendation). Change	9	Risk IC 6 mo+ Moderna -> Dose 4 -> New Preferable Vaccines	311, 312	Added CVX 309, 310	Persons under 5 years of age should be recommended Pfizer (homologous recommendation). CVX 308 (Pfizer) was not added as this should not be recommended for those who received Moderna primary series and are still between the ages of 6 months and 5 years of age.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	6mo - 4 yrs Pfizer -> Dose 4, 5 -> Preferable and Allowable Vaccine End Age for CVX 302	Preferable: n/a
Allowable: 5 years	Preferable: 7 years
Allowable: 7 years	The previous setting was illogical (e.g., preferable wider than allowable). The new settings are based on an upper bound of how old a patient could potentially be since vaccination for this age group began in 2022. That is, no one in this cohort should be over 7 years of age at this point. This may need to be adjusted again when recommendations change or more time passes.
Change	2	12 yrs+ Novavax & WHO Authorized -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	Added interval from CVX codes	This ensures proper spacing should an invalid dose be administered prior to a valid first dose. These were already present in other series, but missing in these two series.

Change	14	18 yrs.+ Pfizer -> Booster Doses 3, 4, 5 Strategy	Dose 3 and 4 for monovalent boosting.	Doses 3 and 4 supports monovalent boosting and bivalent boosting when monovalent boosting hasn't occurred.
Dose 5 supports bivalent boosting when 2 doses of monovalent boosting has occurred.	At the time bivalent boosters are recommended, patients may have received 0, 1, or 2 monovalent boosters. Regardless of previous monovalent boosters, all patients are recommended a bivalent booster. 
- For those who received 2 monovalent boosters, Doses 3 and 4 support evaluation of those doses based on the intervals at that time.
- For those who received 1 monovalent booster, Dose 3 will support evaluation of those doses based on the intervals at that time. 
- Bivalent boosters are overlayed across Dose 3, 4, and 5. A bivalent will always be forecasted until a bivalent dose is administered. Once a bivalent booster is administered, any subsequent doses are skipped.

This strategy is used for other series as well when a patient could have received monovalent doses. More detailed changes for Pfizer boosting are documented in the cells directly below.

Target Disease	COVID-19

Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised Start at 6 mo - 4 yrs Pfizer series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Indication	Recipient of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant (004)	Administer to recipients of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant [HSCT] within 2 years of successful transplantation.	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	7 years	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	7 years	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Active treatment for solid tumors (189)	Administer to persons receiving active treatment for solid tumors	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	Active treatment for hematologic malignancies (190)	Administer to persons receiving active treatment for hematologic malignancies	6 months	7 years	n/a
Indication	Receipt of CAR-T-cell therapy (191)	Administer to persons receiving CAR-T-cell therapy	6 months	7 years	n/a

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised Start at 5 yrs+ Pfizer series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	5 years	n/a	n/a

Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	5 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	5 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 6 mo+ Moderna series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	6 months	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 18 yrs+ Janssen series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	18 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	18 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	18 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 12 yrs+ Novavax
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised Start at 5 yrs+ Mixed Product series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	HIV/AIDS - Severely immunocompromised (154)	Administer to persons who have HIV/AIDS and are severely immunocompromised [See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised"].	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	5 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	5 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	5 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before initiation or resumption of therapy.

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised WHO-Authorized series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	Additional clinical considerations including boosting strategies for persons vaccinated outside the U.S. can be found here: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us-appendix.html
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Series Name	Risk Immunocompromised 18 yrs+ Medicago Clinical Trial Series
Target Disease	COVID-19
Vaccine Group	COVID-19
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	People with known current SARS-CoV-2 infection should defer any COVID-19 vaccination at least until recovery from the acute illness (if symptoms were present) and criteria to discontinue isolation have been met.
Administrative Guidance	If clinical trial participants have questions about whether they should receive an additional and/or booster dose outside of the clinical trial, they should consult with their healthcare provider. Clinical trial participants who did not receive all the recommended doses, or who received other vaccines not listed above, should consult with their healthcare provider to determine if they should receive an FDA-approved or FDA-authorized COVID-19 vaccine series.
Administrative Guidance	A patients clinical team is best positioned to determine the degree of immune compromise and appropriate timing of vaccination.

Factors to consider in assessing the general level of immune competence in a patient include disease severity, duration, clinical stability, complications, comorbidities, and any potentially immune-suppressing treatment.
Administrative Guidance	People who are moderately or severely immunocompromised have the option to receive 1 additional dose of updated (2023-2024 formula) mRNA vaccine. Further additional dose(s) may be administered, informed by the clinical judgement of a healthcare provider and personal preference and circumstances. Any further additional doses should be administered at least 2 months after the last COVID-19 vaccine dose.
Administrative Guidance	COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines may now be administered without regard to timing. This includes simultaneous administration of COVID-19 vaccines and other vaccines (including flu and RSV) on the same day. People, particularly adolescent or young male adults, might consider waiting 4 weeks after orthopoxvius vaccination.
Administrative Guidance	People ages 18 years and older who completed primary vaccination using any COVID-19 vaccine and have not received any previous booster dose(s) may receive a monovalent Novavax booster dose at least 6 months after completion of the primary series if they are unable to receive an mRNA vaccine (i.e., mRNA vaccine contraindicated or not available) or unwilling to receive an mRNA vaccine and would otherwise not receive a booster dose.
Administrative Guidance	For people who have a history of myocarditis with MIS-C or MIS-A, see https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/covid-19/clinical-considerations/interim-considerations-us.html#covid19-vaccination-misc-misa

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	6 months	n/a	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	6 months	n/a	n/a

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	Dengue Vaccine - Recommendations of the ACIP, United States, 2021 - https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/70/rr/pdfs/rr7006a1-H.pdf
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Standard Series	This series starts with the standard 5 dose series for children < 7 years old.  It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered after 4 years.
Diphtheria standard series	Doses 6, 7, and 8 address adolescent doses of Tdap/Td based on the number of valid doses received < 7 years. 
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 9 is the adolescent (11-12 year) dose.
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 10 is the recurring dose

Start at 12 months Series	This series has the same structure as the standard series, but is for patients who receive their first dose on or after 12 months of age. 
	Doses 1-5 are the standard 5 dose series for children < 7 years old.  It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered after 4 years.
Diphtheria standard series	Doses 6, 7, and 8 address adolescent doses of Tdap/Td based on the number of valid doses received < 7 years. 
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 9 is the adolescent (11-12 year) dose.
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 10 is the recurring dose

Version	1.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on all doses	All DTaP containing  vaccines had a vaccine type end age of 11 years	Changed to 19 years for all DTaP containing vaccines	Per 2014 Childhood/Adolescent Harmonized schedule - DTaP can be inadvertently administered through 18 years (less than 19 years) and be counted as the adolescent Tdap booster dose.

Version	1.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on last dose	Only Td and Tdap based vaccines were listed as allowable vaccines	Carried all allowable vaccines from the previous dose down to the last dose.	Since the last dose could actually be administered at 7 years old, an allowable administration of DTaP and other allowable vaccines in the previous dose could still be administered and be considered valid.
Change	2	Skip Dose on Dose 9 in Series	N/A	Added a Trigger Target Dose value of 8 to properly skip the adolescent dose (dose 9) if dose 8 was satisfied	Td can be either recommended starting at 7 or 11 years depending upon DTaP administrations.  Previously, the supporting data would recommend a dose at 7 AND at 11 in certain situations.  This allows for skipping the 11 year recommendation if the child is recommended and receives dose(s) between 7 through 10 years.  Either dose 8 or 9 must be satisfied, but not both.
Change	3	Interval on Dose 9	Interval was specified	Removed Interval on 11 year Adolescent dose	A child who is "fully vaccinated" for DTaP by age 7 years is to be recommended for Tdap at age 11 years without regard to interval.  Similarly, the adolescent dose of Tdap can be administered without regard to interval from the last DTaP dose.  This is not the case, however, when the child enters age 7 years and is not fully vaccinated for DTaP and this is addressed in dose 6, 7, and 8 (catch-up doses) in the series.
Change	4	Dose 10	Not Specified in previous version.	Dose 10 added	Previously Dose 9 was the adolescent dose as well as the recurring 10 year booster dose.  These two requirements were separated into two different doses. Dose 9 is now the adolescent dose and Dose 10 is the recurring 10 year booster.

Version	1.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Latest Recommended Interval on Dose 9	N/A	10 years + 4 weeks	Based on clarification from NIPInfo.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous 	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferrable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Substitute Dose	Missing conditions	Added substitutions to dose 6 for a child who is up-to-date to properly substitute the catch-up doses	A child who is up-to-date at age 7, doesn't need to go through the catch-up doses (6, 7, and 8).  This was missing in version 1.0 and forcing the child through the catch-up doses.
Change	4	Catch-up Doses 6 - 8 Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals	Values not specified	Added Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals to match the Earliest Recommended Age and Earliest Recommended Intervals for each dose.	These were empty before which resulted in a forecast with no Past Due Date.  Since the child is in catch-up at this point, the Past Due Date should align with the Recommended Date.
Change	5	Age Values on Dose 9	Values not specified	Absolute Minimum Age: 7 years Minimum Age: 11 Years Earliest Recommended Age: 11 Years Latest Recommended Age: 13 Years	There were no age values on the recurring dose which resulted in the 11 year dose for a child who was up-to-date with childhood DTaP as incorrect.
faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for tetanus?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/dtap.html  http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/tdap-td.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about diphtheria?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_diph.asp	n/a
FAQs	Is there a maximum number of doses of DTaP a child should receive?	ACIP recommends that children receive no more than 6 doses of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids (e.g., DT, DTaP, DTP) before the seventh birthday because of concern about adverse reactions, primarily local reactions	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_tet.asp	Each of the first 5 doses in the standard series has Conditional Skip logic indicating that receiving 6 or more doses before the age of the 7 is sufficient grounds for skipping the dose.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

The lone non-U.S. vaccine at this time has specific dosing requirements (a different vaccine for dose 1 vs. dose 2) that is not captured in the unspecified code. As such, this code is not included in any tabs beyond the overview tab.

HepA 2-dose series	A standard 2-dose series at age 12 months and 18 months.

HepA risk 1-dose series	A 1-dose series at age 6 months through 12 months.

HepA risk 2-dose series	 A 2-dose series for patients at increased risk or seeking protection.

changeHistory:
Version	4.42	Publication Date: 04/07/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	2-dose -> Dose 2 -> Age -> Latest Recommended Age	24 months + 4 weeks	n/a	Table 3-2 in the general recs has removed the upper bound on Dose 2 of Hep A.

Version	4.41	Publication Date: 03/07/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose -> Dose 1 -> Age	12 months - 4 days 12 months 12 months 24 months + 4 weeks	12 months - 4 days 19 years 19 years n/a	Risk recommendations for Hep A begin at age 19 years of age. All persons under 19 are recommended vaccination through age-based recommendations. Absolute Minimum Age was retained at 12 months - 4 days to support previous vaccination that can count towards Risk-based vaccination.
Change	2	Risk Twinrix 3-dose -> Dose 1 -> Age	18 years - 4 days 18 years 18 years n/a	18 years - 4 days 19 years 19 years n/a	Risk recommendations for Hep A begin at age 19 years of age. All persons under 19 are recommended vaccination through age-based recommendations. Absolute Minimum Age was retained at 18 years - 4 days to support previous vaccination that can count towards Risk-based vaccination.
Change	3	Risk Twinrix 4-dose -> Dose 1 -> Age	18 years - 4 days 18 years 18 years n/a	18 years - 4 days 19 years 19 years n/a	Risk recommendations for Hep A begin at age 19 years of age. All persons under 19 are recommended vaccination through age-based recommendations. Absolute Minimum Age was retained at 18 years - 4 days to support previous vaccination that can count towards Risk-based vaccination.

Version	4.29
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Antigen Series Overview tab	n/a	Added CVX 193 (Twinrix Jr.)	This CVX was added to the overview tab and is noted as not counting towards U.S. vaccination per recently updated errata to the General Best Practices (April 26, 2022). Since this does not count, this CVX is not in any other tabs which would result in a valid dose.

Version	4.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications -> Illicit Drug Users -> Administrative Guidance	n/a	includes persons who use injections or non-injection drugs (i.e., all who use illegal drugs)	Added administrative guidance to incorporate 2020 MMWR.
Change	2	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	Code 044 (International Adoptee)	Updated language associated with code	Entire code language was updated to incorporate 2020 MMWR language. Previous MMWR language referenced "close contact with international adoptee within first 60 days" new language is "anticipate close personal contact". Also added administrative guidance
Change	3	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	Working with Hepatitis A virus in research setting (049)	Removed	This was sub-grouped in the 2020 MMWR as a category under code 059 (see next change log entry)
Change	4	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications -> Occupational Exposure (059) -> Administrative Guidance	n/a	Includes persons who work with HAV-infected nonhuman primates or with clinical or nonclinical material containing HAV in a research laboratory setting should be vaccinated. No other occupational groups (e.g., health care providers or food handlers) have been demonstrated to be at increased risk for HAV infection because of occupational exposure	Updated Administrative guidance to incorporate 2020 MMWR language describing occupation exposure settings.
Change	5	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	n/a	Persons at risk during an outbreak (070)	Added new indication per 2020 MMWR
Change	6	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications -> Homelessness (121) -> Administrative Guidance	n/a	A homeless person is defined as 1) a person who lacks housing (regardless of whether the person is a member of a family), including a person whose primary residence during...<cut for brevity>	Added administrative guidance to incorporate 2020 MMWR.
Change	7	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	HIV/AIDS codes (154 and 155)	Removed	Removed and replace with new code for HIV Infection (Code 186) per MMWR language
Change	8	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	n/a	Persons in settings that provide services to adults with high proportion of those persons have risk factors for HAV infection (185)	Added new indication per 2020 MMWR
Change	9	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	n/a	HIV Infection (186)	Added new indication per 2020 MMWR. This single code replaces codes 154 and 155 which included immunocompromising severity and AIDS which aren't relevant for HepA vaccination.

Version	4.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications -> Administrative Guidance for Chronic Liver Disease (015)	n/a	includes, but is not limited to persons with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, cirrhosis, fatty liver disease, alcoholic liver disease, autoimmune hepatitis, or an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) or aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level persistently greater than twice the upper limit of normal 	Harmonization efforts between Hep A and Hep B Risk Series.
Change	2	All risk series (except 1-dose travel series) -> Indications	Receives clotting factor concentrates (006)	Removed	This was removed as a risk factor for vaccination by ACIP in the July 3, 2020 MMWR

Version	4.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose and Twinrix Series Indications	N/A	Added new indication for Patient seeks Hepatitis A protection (175)	Existing "Patient Seeks Protection" code (001) remains, but that applies to multiple diseases, this code is specific to Hepatitis A.

Version	4.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose and Twinrix Series Indications	N/A	Added two new indications for HIV	ACIP voted in June 2019 to routinely recommend HepA to persons with HIV.

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Twinrix 3-dose Allowable Vaccine End Age	N/A	19 years for CVX 31 and 83	CVX codes 31 and 83 are pediatric formulations and should not be considered past age 19 years per Ask the Experts. This was properly set in other series, but the End Age was omitted in the Risk Twinrix 3-dose series.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Infant traveler risk series (1-dose)	n/a	New Risk 1-dose series added	New ACIP recommendations include a single dose for infants travelling internationally.
Change	4	Risk 2-dose, Risk Twinrix 3-dose, Risk Twinrix 4-dose indications	N/A	Added Homelessness indication 	Added homelessness as a indication in the Risk 2-dose, Twinrix 3 dose, and Twinrix 4-dose series per 2019 harmonized schedules

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccines in Twinrix series	CVX 104 was only a preferable vaccine.	Added CVX 104 (Twinrix) to allowable vaccines.	These should have been allowable, but were omitted in development on the Twinrix specific series.
Change	2	New Allowable Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX 31 (HepA, peds, unspecified) to allowable vaccines.	This should have been allowable in several spots, but was omitted.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	HepA Abbreviation	Hep A	HepA	Other CDSi resources used Hep A or HepA.  All resources are being updated to reflect the abbreviations used by ACIP for consistency purposes.
Change	2	Vaccine Type End Age for both doses of the 2-dose standard series	n/a	19 years	Vaccines using CVX codes 83 and 104 contain a lower dose of antigen which is only valid for non-adults.
Change	3	Preferable Vaccine for Dose 2 of the 2-dose risk series	CVX code 83 was preferable under the age of 19 years	The code is now not preferable	The at risk indications only begin at age 19 so a valid second dose would not be possible before this age.
Change	4	Allowable Vaccine for Dose 2 of the 2-dose risk series	CVX codes 83 and 104 were allowable	Neither code is now not allowable	The lower dose of Hep A in these two vaccines is not valid for an adult.
Change	5	Maximum Age of Dose 1 of the 2-dose series	n/a	19 years	The standard series ends at age 19 years after which, a patient must have an indication to require vaccination.
Change	6	Allowable interval on the 2nd does in the Risk 2-dose series	n/a	6 months from dose 1	The new (April 2017) ACIP Best Practice Guidelines notes an administration pattern where if the last dose is separated by 6 months from the 1st dose, Hep A can be considered complete.  This was already in the standard 2-dose series for children, but not in the risk 2-dose series.
Change	7	Dose 3 absolute minimum interval in Risk Twinrix 3-dose series	6 months from dose 1	6 months - 4 days from dose 1	Grace period is allowed to be used here, but was missing.

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for hepatitis A?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/hepa.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about hepatitis A?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_hepa.asp	n/a
FAQs	Single antigen HepA vaccine is an Allowable Vaccine for all doses in the 3-dose Twinrix series. Doesn't that mean that an individual could complete the Twinrix series without getting any doses of Twinrix?	Yes, a subject matter expert at the CDC confirmed that an individual would be considered fully protected with 3 doses of HepA single antigen vaccine on the Twinrix schedule. Because this schedule is intended for use with Twinrix, we have elected to keep the tradename in the series name.	n/a	HepA is allowable for all 3 doses in the Twinrix 3-dose series.
FAQs	In the 2-dose series, the Preferable Interval and Allowable Interval look suspiciously like the same thing, why are both necessary?	The Preferable Interval is 6 months from the immediately previous dose which may be invalid if an attempted second dose was administered before 6 months. However the April 2017 ACIP Best Practice Guidelines notes an administration pattern where if the last dose is separated by 6 months from the 1st dose, Hep A can be considered complete. The Allowable Interval accounts for this possibility.	https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/timing.html	Both the Preferable and Allowable interval is populated for dose 2 of a 2-dose series.
FAQs	In the Risk 2-dose series why are CVX codes 83 and 104 allowable for the first dose but not the second dose?	Doses of CVX 83 and 104 contain a lower dose of antigen which is only valid for persons under the age of 19 years. The 2-dose risk series for adults only, but if a patient received one dose before the age of 19 years it still counts towards completion of the first dose of the series. It is expected that the second dose will occur after the age of 19 years (otherwise the patient will have completed the equivalent 2-dose standard series) and so these CVX codes will not be valid.	n/a	CVX codes 83 and 104 are only allowable for the first dose.
FAQs	How can the supporting data be used to recommend Hepatitis A to all adults?	Once support of risk series is implemented, by assigning an indication of "Patient seeks protection (001)" to all individuals of the appropriate age, vaccination against Hepatitis A will be recommended.	n/a	n/a
FAQs	Is there a minimum interval between the infant travel dose (6 through 11 months) from the Risk 1-dose series and the initial dose of the standard 2-dose series?	No, there is no minimum interval between those two doses.	CDC subject matter experts	Dose 1 of the standard 2-dose series has no minimum interval

Indication	Homelessness (121)	Administer to persons who are experiencing homelessness.	19 years	n/a	A homeless person is defined as 1) a person who lacks housing (regardless of whether the person is a member of a family), including a person whose primary residence during the night is a supervised public or private facility (e.g., shelter) that provides temporary living accommodations and a person who is a resident in transitional housing, 2) a person without permanent housing who might live on the streets; or stay in a shelter, mission, single-room occupancy facility, abandoned building, vehicle, or any other unstable or nonpermanent situation, or 3) who is doubled up, a term that refers to a situation where persons are unable to maintain their housing situation and are forced to stay with a series of friends or extended family members. In addition, previously homeless persons who are to be released from a prison or a hospital might be considered homeless if they do not have a stable housing situation to which they can return.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf

SERIES GROUP 1 | STANDARD

HepB 3-dose series	A 3-dose standard series

HepB 4-dose series	The HepB 4-dose series is designed to be compatible with other vaccine group series; the use of combination vaccines often results in an extra (4th) dose of HepB.
HepB 4-dose series	This series accommodates this without marking the extra HepB dose as being invalid.

HepB adolescent 2-dose series	2-dose series separated by at least 4 months of adult formulation Recombivax HB is licensed for use in children aged 11 through 15 years

19+ 3-dose	A 3-dose series for those who begin vaccination on/after 19 years of age.

HepB-CpG 2-dose series	A 2-dose standard series

HepB-CpG 4-dose Mixed Use Series	A 4-dose standard series where the first dose is a non-Heplisav-B vaccine

CpG-HepB 4-dose Mixed Use Series	A 4-dose standard series where the first dose is Heplisav-B vaccine followed by a non-Heplisav-B vaccine

Twinrix 3 Dose Series	A 3-dose Twinrix series.

Twinrix 4-dose series	A 4-dose Twinrix series.

SERIES GROUP 2 | RISK

HepB risk 3-dose series	A 3-dose Series for patients at increased risk or seeking protection

HepB-CpG risk 2-dose series	A 2-dose Series for patients at increased risk or seeking protection

Risk HepB-CpG 4-dose Mixed Use Series	A 4-dose standard series where the first dose is a non-Heplisav-B vaccine

Risk CpG-HepB 4-dose Mixed Use Series	A 4-dose standard series where the first dose is Heplisav-B vaccine followed by a non-Heplisav-B vaccine

HepB risk Twinrix 3 Dose Series	A 3-dose Twinrix series for adults who are at increased risk or seeking protection

HepB risk Twinrix 4-dose series	A 4-dose Twinrix series for adults who are at increased risk or seeking protection

HepB risk Dialysis 4-dose series	A 4-dose Series with annual booster for patients at increased risk due to end stage renal disease. Includes coverage for Engerix, Heplisav-B, Mixed product, and standard series prior to dialysis.

HepB risk Dialysis Recombivax 3-dose series	A 3-dose Series with annual booster for patients at increased risk due to end stage renal disease

Version	4.32
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	3-dose series -> Select Patient Series -> Maximum Age To Start	n/a	19 years	Created a specific 3-dose series for Adults (defined by ACIP as 19 years+). This current childhood series includes catch-up rules when children are behind schedule and condenses intervals for dose 2 and 3. These rules should not apply to adults. Separating childhood series from Adult series resolves this.
Change	2	19+ 3-dose Series	n/a	New Series	Created to support Adult recommendations of 0, 1, and 6 months without catch-up rules.
Change	3	Risk Recombivax 3-dose -> Dose 4 -> Preferable Interval -> Absolute Minimum Interval	1 year - 4 days	0 days	Dose 4 is a recurring dose on a 1 year interval regardless if the dose is valid or not. Marking a dose under 1 year as invalid can lead to confusion with clinicians since the recommendation to repeat is another year. Moving down to 0 days validates the dose and recommends another dose in 1 year which is on the recurring schedule. This same approach is used in Td recurring doses.
Change	4	Risk Dialysis 4-dose -> Dose 5 -> Preferable Interval -> Absolute Minimum Interval	1 year - 4 days	0 days	Dose 5 is a recurring dose on a 1 year interval regardless if the dose is valid or not. Marking a dose under 1 year as invalid can lead to confusion with clinicians since the recommendation to repeat is another year. Moving down to 0 days validates the dose and recommends another dose in 1 year which is on the recurring schedule. This same approach is used in Td recurring doses.

Version	1.9
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	HepB 2-Dose Adolescent Series ->  Select Patient Series -> Maximum Age To Start	Not Specified	16 years - 4 months	Previously, this series would be selected as the best series if a dose of Recombivax Adult was administered on or after 11 years of age.  This should be the case up until the point where the series cannot be completed.  That is, if the first dose is administered on or after 16 years - 4 months of age, the series cannot be completed since the interval is 4 months.  Adding 16 years - 4 months for the Maximum Age To Start the series will produce the desired result to not further recommend a second dose in 4 months which would be after age 16 years.

Version	1.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	HepB 4-Dose Series    -> Dose 3           -> Age	Fully specified	Removed age requirements	Based on guidance from EIPB, the 3rd dose can be "dropped out" when validating a 4-dose administration.  As such, the age requirements were removed to allow the 3rd dose to be valid.
Change	2	HepB 4-Dose Series    -> Dose 3           -> Interval	Fully specified	Removed interval requirements	Based on guidance from EIPB, the 3rd dose can be "dropped out" when validating a 4-dose administration.  As such, the interval requirements were removed to allow the 3rd dose to be valid.
Change	3	HepB 4-Dose Series    -> Dose 4           -> Interval	Three intervals were specified * 16 weeks from dose 1 * 8 weeks from dose 2 * 1 week from previous dose	Updated intervals are: * 16 weeks from dose 1 * 8 weeks from previous dose	Based on guidance from EIPB the 4th dose should be forecasted similar to the traditional 3rd dose.  As such, the interval requirements were updated to reflect this.
Change	4	HepB 4-Dose Series  -> Dose 4     -> Allowable Interval	Not Specified	Now specified to be 16 weeks - 4 days from dose 1	Based on guidance from EIPB the 4th dose can be considered valid as long as it is 24 weeks - 4 days of age and 16 weeks - 4 days from dose 1.  It is not necessary to retain the 8 week interval from the previous dose for validation purposes.  As such, the allowable interval is used to specify this requirement.
Change	5	HepB 4-Dose Series   -> All Doses      -> Maximum Age	7 Years	Removed	This series originally started to serve Pediarix specifically which has an upper age of 7 years.  Now that this series is designed to validate all HepB vaccines, this upper bound is no longer needed.

Version	1.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	HepB 4-Dose Series (Comvax)	HepB 4-Dose Series (Comvax)	Removed entire series.	Based on guidance from EIPB, the 4-dose series for HepB should not be forecasted, but validated after the fact.  Given this notion, only one 4-dose series is needed which can handle all combinations of products.  Previously, the two 4-dose series had a large amount of overlap with this series focusing on forecasting Comvax specific forecasting for Hib alignment.

Target Disease	HepB
