Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	Test all vaccinees for anti-HBs 1-2 months after the last primary vaccine dose, to determine their response to the vaccine (adequate response is defined as at least 10 mIU/mL). Patients and staff members who do not respond to the primary vaccine series should be revaccinated with three additional doses and retested for response. No additional series should be administered (i.e., a 3rd full series). The patient should receive yearly boosters starting 1 year after completion of the second series.
Administrative Guidance	Retest patients who respond to the vaccine annually for anti-HBs. If anti-HBs declines to less than 10 mIU/mL, administer a booster dose of hepatitis B vaccine and continue to retest annually. Retesting immediately after the booster dose is not necessary. For staff members who respond to the vaccine, booster doses of vaccine are not necessary, and periodic serologic testing to monitor antibody concentrations is not recommended
Administrative Guidance	Routine childhood vaccination against hepatitis B has been recommended since 1991 and routine adolescent vaccination since 1995. Thus, many persons who develop end-stage renal failure will have a history of vaccination against hepatitis B. These persons should have responded to the vaccine when their immune status was normal, but if their anti-HBs levels are less than 10 mIU/mL when they begin dialysis, they should be revaccinated with a complete primary series.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Hib start at 2 months 4-dose series	This series defines the standard 4 dose minimum and recommended ages.
Hib start at 2 months 4-dose series	Additionally, it defines catch-up schedules (via skip dose) where a child gets dose 1 (or dose 1 and dose 2) at roughly the appropriate time and then lapses.

Hib start at 7 months 3-dose series	This series defines the 3 dose catch-up schedule for children who get their first dose on or after 7 months of age.
Hib start at 7 months 3-dose series	It includes the situation for when a child gets a shot at 7 months, then lapses until on or after age of 15 months via the skip dose on dose 2.

Hib start at 12 months 2-dose series	This series defines the 2 dose catch-up schedule for children who get their first dose on or after 12 months of age.

Hib start at 15 months 1-dose series	This series defines the 1 dose catch-up schedule for children who get their first dose on or after 15 months of age.

Hib PRP-OMP 3-dose series	This series defines the minimum and recommended ages and catch-up schedules for the 3 dose Hib series applied when CVX codes 49 and 51 are used for the primary series

Hib risk child 2-dose series	2-dose series for patients between the ages of 12 and 60 months who are at increased risk.

Hib risk 1-dose series	1-dose series for patients at risk.

Hib risk 3-dose series	3-dose series for patients who have received a hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Removed Vaccine Contraindication	n/a	Removed Allergic Reaction to Latex (104)	This has been removed as a contraindication in the 2024 yearly childhood schedule.

Version	4.47	Publication Date: 09/18/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	5	Risk child 2-dose -> New Indications	n/a	Added new indications: - Radiation therapy - Chemotherapy - HIV Infection	These were previously missing
Change	6	Risk child 2-dose -> Dose 1 -> Skip Condition removed	Dose is not required if the patient has received 1 or more doses on or after the age of 12 months	Removed	Removed skip condition in favor of new skip condition (Next change) which aligns ACIP published language
Change	7	Risk child 2-dose -> Dose 1 -> New Skip Condition	n/a	New Skip Condtion:  Dose is not required if the patient has received 2 or more doses before the age of 12 months	New skip condition which aligns ACIP published language
Change	8	Risk child 2-dose -> Dose 2 -> Both Skip Conditions removed	2 existing skip conditions:  1) Dose is not required if the patient has received 2 or more doses before the age of 12 months  2) Dose is not required if the patient has received 2 or more doses on or after the age of 12 months	Removed both skip condtions	With changes to dose 1 skip conditions, these skip conditions are no longer necessary.

Version	4.45	Publication Date: 07/27/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Start at 7 Months -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval	This was added as a safeguard against an edge case which was resulting in a second dose administered on or after 7 months of age, but less than 4 weeks from the previous dose incorrectly evaluating the patient's immunization history. This ensures patients who have an invalid second dose on/after 7 months of age and less than 4 weeks from the previous dose are properly evaluated.
Change	2	Start at 12 Months -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval	This was added as a safeguard against an edge case which was resulting in a second dose administered on or after 12 months of age, but less than 4 weeks from the previous dose incorrectly evaluating the patient's immunization history. This ensures patients who have an invalid second dose on/after 12 months of age and less than 4 weeks from the previous dose are properly evaluated.

Version	4.44	Publication Date: 06/06/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Start at 15 Months -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval	This was added as a safeguard against an edge case which was resulting in a second dose administered on or after 15 months of age, but less than 8 weeks from the previous dose incorrectly evaluating the patient's immunization history and incorrectly considering the patient complete. This ensures the final dose is at least 8 weeks removed from any previous dose.

Version	4.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 1-dose series -> Indications	HIV/AIDS codes (154 and 155)	Removed	Removed and replace with new code for HIV Infection (Code 186) per MMWR language
Change	2	Risk 1-dose series -> Indications	n/a	HIV Infection (186)	Added new indication per MMWR language. This single code replaces codes 154 and 155 which included immunocompromising severity and AIDS which aren't relevant for Hib vaccination.

Version	4.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccines	n/a	New CVX (198) was added to the following series: * Start at 2 months 4-dose * Start at 7 months 3-dose * Start at 12 months 2-dose * Start at 15 months 1-dose * PRP-OMP 3-dose * Risk child 2-dose * Risk 1-dose	Per updated CVX listing on CDC code tables
Change	2	Vaccine Contraindications in Contraindications tab	n/a	Added new CVX (198) to existing Vaccine-Specific Contraindications	Contraindications are specific to pertussis-containing vaccines.

Version	4.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Preferred vaccines in all "Start at *" childhood series	CVX 146 was not included as a preferred vaccine	Added CVX as a preferred vaccine where appropriate per MMWR	MMWR published on February 7, 2020: https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/pdfs/mm6905a5-H.pdf
Change	2	Contraindications	n/a	Added two new vaccine-specific Contraindications to support CVX 146 (Vaxelis)	Per package insert: https://www.fda.gov/media/119465/download

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Conditional Skip in Standard Series	One conditional Skip for both Evaluation and Forecasting	Expanded Conditional Skip to split into Evaluation and Forecasting Conditional Sets.	This allows for proper skipping when doses or the patient is near the skip ages and intervals.
	4	Minimum Age To Start for Risk 2-dose, Risk 1-dose and Risk 3-dose series	N/A	12 months, 15 months and 6 weeks	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age
	5	Series Equivalency in Risk child 2-dose	1	N/A	This is handled through detailed conditional skips as this series is not always exactly equivalent to standard series completion (i.e., one dose at 15 months)
Change	6	Conditional Skip in Risk Child 2-dose Series	N/A	Added Conditional Skips to properly skip or forecast doses based on doses received prior to start of this series.	Previously, this was handled through Series Equivalency, but that incorrectly considered a patient complete when further doses were needed.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Conditional Skip for Risk 1-dose series	A Completed Series warranted skipping the first (and only) dose	Conditional Skip logic has been removed	Given that the Risk 1-dose series is considered equivalent to any series in Series Group 1, the previous Conditional Skip logic was redundant.
Change	2	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

HPV 2-dose series	2 dose series for those with a first dose before the age of 15 years

HPV 3-dose series	3 dose series for those with a first dose after the age of 15 years

HPV 3-dose SCDM series	3 dose series to support Shared Clinical Decision Making from 27-45 years of age

HPV male 2-dose series	2 dose male series for those with a first dose before the age of 15 years

HPV male 3-dose series	3 dose male series for those with a first dose after the age of 15 years

HPV male 3-dose SCDM series	3 dose male series to support Shared Clinical Decision Making from 27-45 years of age.

HPV risk 2-dose series	2 dose series for persons at increased risk that need an early start.

HPV risk male 2-dose series	2 dose male series for persons at increased risk that need an early start.

HPV risk 3-dose series	3 dose series for persons at increased risk.

HPV risk male 3-dose series	3 dose male series for persons at increased risk.
changeHistory:
Version	4.45	Publication Date: 07/27/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 3-dose & Risk male 3-dose -> Equivalent Series Group	1	n/a	A patient who is under the age of 15 years and not immunocompromised can receive 2 doses to be considered complete. A patient who is under 15 years of age and is immunocompromised is recommended to receive 3 doses of HPV. These are not equivalent series groups.
Change	2	3-dose & male 3-dose -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval	This was added as a safeguard against an edge case which was resulting in a second dose administered on or after 15 years of age, but less than 4 weeks from the previous dose incorrectly evaluating the patient's immunization history.
Change	3	3-dose, 3-dose SCDM, Male 3-dose, & Male 3-dose SCDM -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Interval -> Earliest & Latest Recommended Interval from previous dose	4 months 5 months + 4 weeks	n/a n/a	To harmonize with the 2-dose series when a 3rd dose is needed, the earliest and latest recommended interval were removed. This will create a uniform 3rd dose forecast when a 3rd doses is necessary regardless of age.

Version	4.27
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	3-dose SCDM -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Intervals	2 intervals defined	Added a third interval for spacing back to target dose #1 if the dose as administered prior to 12/15/2016	This was omitted on this series upon creation. It is the same interval that is present in other 3-dose series.

Version	4.26
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New Series for Shared Clinical Decision Making	n/a	Two new series  * 3-dose SCDM * Male 3-dose SCDM	HPV recommendations include Shared Clinical Decision Making (SCDM) for those 27-45 who are not adequately vaccinated. These two new series will not be recommended until a first dose is administered to someone on or after 27 years of age.
Change	2	All non-SCDM series -> Dose 2&3 -> Age -> Maximum Age	27 years	n/a	HPV recommendations include Shared Clinical Decision Making (SCDM) for those 27-45 who are not adequately vaccinated. Removing the Maximum Age on Dose 2 and 3 enables these series to be finished in support of SCDM starting at age 27 years of age.
Change	3	Administrative Guidance on Age-based standard schedules  (Male) 2-dose, (Male) 3-dose	n/a	ACIP recommends routine HPV vaccination at age 11 or 12 years. Vaccination can be given starting at age 9 years.	HPV recommendations include Shared Clinical Decision Making (SCDM) for those 9-10. Administrative Guidance was added to support this portion of the ACIP recommendations.

Version	4.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 3-dose & Risk mail 3-dose series -> Indications	HIV/AIDS codes (154 and 155)	Removed	Removed and replace with new code for HIV Infection (Code 186) per MMWR language
Change	2	Risk 3-dose & Risk mail 3-dose series -> Indications	n/a	HIV Infection (186)	Added new indication per MMWR language. This single code replaces codes 154 and 155 which included immunocompromising severity and AIDS which aren't relevant for HPV vaccination.

Version	4.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Preferable Vaccine Type End Age (all instances)	27 years	46 years	HPV9 is licensed up to 46 years (i.e., through 45 years). This is a licensure setting of the product. It does not impact the routine age of the recommendations through age 26 years.
Change	2	Max age	N/A	27 years	In doses which did not have a Max Age of through 26 years (i.e., less than 27 years), 27 years was added based on updated guidance. At 27 years, all doses are Shared Clinical Decision Making even if the patient started vaccination prior to age 27 years.

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Recommendations for Transgender persons	Transgender was a coded observation	Removed Transgender as a coded observation in Risk Series and moved to a Gender in all Female Series	Moved to a gender in several series now that all upper age ranges are harmonized by ACIP (June 2019) allowing for scheduling to align. Associated with female series as that series has more allowable vaccines than the male series. This will allow for historical doses of HPV to be considered valid and assume the provider administered an appropriate product. See below on series renaming.
Change	2	Series Name across all "female" series	Female 2-dose; Female 3-dose etc.…	2-dose; 3-dose; etc.	Removed the female from series name historically dedicated to female and unknown genders. As noted above, Transgender was incorporated into these series. Male series is still necessary for historical purposes which do not allow all of the same products to be considered valid.
Change	3	Maximum Age in all Male Series	22 years	27 years	ACIP voted in June 2019 to harmonize the maximum age to 27 years for all persons
Change	4	Risk Male 3-dose series indication	Men who have sex with men (036)	Removed Indication	This is no longer necessary as an Indication for the Risk Male 3-dose series. Previously, this was necessary as Male recommendations stopped at age 22, but are now harmonized out to 27 years of age. All Males should receive 2 or 3 doses up to 27 years of age.
Change	5	Preferable Interval for Dose 3 of all 3-dose series	16 weeks	16 weeks - 4 days	Footnotes M and N in table 3-1 of the General Best Practice Guidelines for Immunizations (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/timing.html) allows the use of the 4 day grace period.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Preferable Interval for Dose 3 of all 3-dose series	Minimum Interval of 5 months	Alternate Minimum Interval of 16 weeks	An alternate Minimum Interval was added to support a historical recommendation from 2016.
Change	4	Minimum Age To Start for all Risk series	N/A	9 years	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age
Change	5	Indications for  Female and Male Risk 3-dose	N/A	Transgender person (075)	New wording in the harmonized adult schedule
Change	6	Dose 3 Earliest and Latest Recommended Intervals on all 3-dose series.	N/A	4 months and 5 months + 4 weeks	These were missing previously, but are defined in the general best practice recommendations timing and spacing table 3-1.
Change	7	Indication Begin Age for  Female and Male Risk 2-dose	9 years	0 days	The reduced Begin Age will ensure that any history of sexual abuse or assault will result in a recommendation for vaccination beginning at the age of 9 years (the Recommended Minimum Age of Dose 1)

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 2 Earliest Recommended Interval on all 3-dose series.	8 weeks	4 weeks	This was incorrectly set in previous versions.  As noted in the MMWR, Dose 2 should be recommended 1-2 months after the first dose.  Per ACIP rules, a 1 month interval should be treated as 4 weeks.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	HPV 2-dose Male and Female Series -> Default Series	No	Yes	Due to the introduction of a 2-dose and 3-dose series, the 2-dose series were labeled as the default series.
Change	2	HPV Risk 3-dose Series list of Indications	Observations 151, 152, 160 and 161 included in the indication list	Observations 151, 152, 160 and 161 removed from the indication list	The new MMWR (Dec 2016) does not include these observations as indications as clarified by CDC subject matter experts.
Change	3	4vHPV Product	Preferred and Active Product	Removed 4vHPV Gardasil (CVX 62) as a preferable vaccine across all doses and series	4vHPV Gardasil was discontinued and it's last Expiry was the end of May, 2017 per the manufacturer.
Change	4	Contraindications	Vaccine Contraindications	Removed 2vHPV and 4vHPV specific contraindications.  Moved Hypersensitivity to yeast (110) from a Vaccine Contraindication to an Antigen Contraindication	2vHPV and 4vHPV are no longer active products
Change	5	Administrative Guidance	n/a	"At the provider's discretion,"	Administrative Guidance for 3-dose risk series updated to match the new ACIP wording.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Added Pregnancy as a contraindication	To better align with recommendations for administering HPV to women known to be pregnant.
Change	2	Latest Recommended Interval for the second dose of all 2-dose series	13 months	13 months + 4 weeks	The latest recommended interval should include an additional 4 week period before the patient is considered overdue.
Change	3	Earliest and Latest Recommended Interval for the third dose of all 3-dose series	Earliest: 4 months  Latest: 5 months + 4 weeks	Earliest: n/a Latest: n/a	The new MMWR (Dec 2016) does not reference the 4 month interval the previous HPV recommendations did. The new MMWR recommends vaccination 12 weeks after dose 2 and 6 months from dose 1.
Change	4	All 2-dose series.	General Revamp to forecasting and allowance of 3-doses being administered in the 2-dose series.	Modified existing 2-dose series to incorporate the possibility of a third dose and allowing all three doses to be validated and considered valid.	Clarifications were discussed with HPV SMEs based on CDSi implementer questions.  Improvements are documented to align with evaluation and forecasting expectations.  See FAQ tab on 2-dose series question for more information.

FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for HPV?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/hpv.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about HPV?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_hpv.asp	n/a
FAQs	For all 2-dose series, why are there actually three target doses documented?	If the second dose of HPV is administered prior to 5 months from the first, dose, the patient dose can be considered valid and the patient ultimately ends up with 3 valid doses.  This is mildly different than the situation where the patient is expected to receive 3 doses (start at 15 years or immunocompromised).	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/hpv.html	In the recommended administration pattern (0, 6-12 months), the second dose is skipped and doses 1 and 3 are validated.  This is seen in the dose 2 conditional skip attributes by skipping the second dose once 5 months have elapsed since dose 1.  At this point only two doses will be needed.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Influenza standard series	The standard series starts with birth and walks through childhood and adult recommendations via conditional skip (as needed) and recurring dose.
Influenza standard series	This series will be tweaked annually to align with influenza recommendations.
changeHistory:
Version	4.46	Publication Date: 08/24/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All references to Seasonal Begin and End Dates	2022-2023	2023-2024	Updated to reflect new flu season. This impacts several cells in the Standard Series.
Change	2	Standard -> Updated Administrative Guidance	Persons with a history of egg allergy may receive any licensed, recommended influenza vaccine that is otherwise appropriate for their age and health status.	All persons aged 6 months and older with egg allergy should receive influenza vaccine. Any influenza vaccine (egg based or non-egg based) that is otherwise appropriate for the recipient’s age and health status can be used.	Updated to reflect new flu season. This impacts several cells in the Standard Series.
Change	3	Standard -> removed Administrative Guidance	Persons who report having had reactions to egg involving symptoms other than urticaria (e.g., angioedema or swelling, respiratory distress, lightheadedness, or recurrent emesis) or who required epinephrine or another emergency medical intervention should be vaccinated in an inpatient or outpatient medical setting (including, but not necessarily limited to, hospitals, clinics, health departments, and physician offices). Vaccine administration should be supervised by a health care provider who is able to recognize and manage severe allergic reactions.	Removed	ACIP vote removed the need for special attention above and beyond the normal best practices for patient monitoring for any vaccine.

Version	4.42	Publication Date: 04/07/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Antigen Series Overview -> New Vaccine (CVX 231)	n/a	New Southern Hemisphere vaccine (CVX 231)	This was only added to overview tab. Since it is a southern hemisphere flu product, it does not count towards U.S. flu vaccination. As such, it was not added to any other tabs in this spreadsheet.

Version	4.33
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Standard Series -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	ACIP recommends persons aged 65 years and older preferentially receive any one of the following higher dose or adjuvanted influenza vaccines: quadrivalent high-dose inactivated influenza vaccine (HD-IIV4), quadrivalent recombinant influenza vaccine (RIV4), or quadrivalent adjuvanted inactivated influenza vaccine (aIIV4). If none of these three vaccines is available at an opportunity for vaccine administration, then any other age-appropriate influenza vaccine should be used.	New administrative guidance for those persons aged 65 years and older.

series:
Series Name	Influenza standard series
Target Disease	Influenza
Vaccine Group	Influenza
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	ACIP recommends persons aged 65 years and older preferentially receive any one of the following higher dose or adjuvanted influenza vaccines: quadrivalent high-dose inactivated influenza vaccine (HD-IIV4), quadrivalent recombinant influenza vaccine (RIV4), or quadrivalent adjuvanted inactivated influenza vaccine (aIIV4). If none of these three vaccines is available at an opportunity for vaccine administration, then any other age-appropriate influenza vaccine should be used.
Administrative Guidance	All persons aged 6 months and older with egg allergy should receive influenza vaccine. Any influenza vaccine (egg based or non-egg based) that is otherwise appropriate for the recipient's age and health status can be used.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

changeHistory:
Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Supporting Data Revamp	1 series	 Two Series	Based on latest MMWR (07/19/2019), JE now has varied spacing based on age and booster doses. To meet these requirements, the JE supporting data was revamped to reflect the new recommendations.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Minimum Age To Start for Risk 2-dose series	N/A	2 months	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Version	3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
	1	General Update	N/A	Created 	ACIP guidance on Japanese Encephalitis.
Change	2	General Update	From Most Recent (CVX)	From Most Recent (CVX List)	Updated to allow multiple CVX codes to be documented as part of the From Most Recent interval type

series:
Series Name	Japanese Encephalitis risk 2-dose series
Target Disease	Japanese Encephalitis
Vaccine Group	Japanese Encephalitis
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	For adults and children, a booster dose (i.e., third dose) should be given on or after 1 year after completion of the primary JE-VC series if ongoing exposure or reexposure to JE virus is expected
Administrative Guidance	JE vaccination should be considered for shorter-term (e.g., less than 1 month) travel with an increased risk for JE on the basis of planned travel duration, season, location, activities, and accommodations. See JE recommendation box 2 for more detailed information. (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/68/rr/rr6802a1.htm#B2_down)
Administrative Guidance	JE vaccination should be considered for travel to a JE-endemic area but uncertain of specific duration of travel, destination, or activities.
Administrative Guidance	Endemic Area and transmission season is determined by country.  Refer to the yellow book for a definition of the transmission season: http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2014/chapter-3-infectious-diseases-related-to-travel/japanese-encephalitis

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

changeHistory:
Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Removed Contraindication	Immunocompromised (003)	Removed	This was removed as it is too broad and includes all forms of immunocompromise (mild-to-severe).
Change	2	Contraindications -> New Contraindication	n/a	Added Severe Immunocompromise (246)	This was added as a better classification which results in a contraindication.

Version	4.39	Publication Date: 12/13/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New PRIORIX vaccine	n/a	n/a	PRIORIX is the same CVX code as M-M-R II (03) with the same contraindications and is interchangeable in use. No changes were made to any Immunity, Contraindications, or Series tabs. Priorix was added to the overview tab.

Version	4.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 003 (Immunocompromised) was added as a contraindication	This is an existing PHINVADS code exchanged in HL7 (VXC27) and results in a contraindication.

Version	4.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 168 (Chemotherapy) added as a contraindication	This has been a contraindication for quite some time in published recommendations, but was missing in CDSi.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose Series Indication updates	Code 026 (ART) was included	Removed code 026 (ART)	This was removed as a new series was created for ART-specific recommendations. See next change for further details.
Change	4	New Risk 2-dose ART Series	N/A	Created a new Series for patients who undergo antiviral therapy (ART)	Previously ART was included in the Risk 2-dose series, but wasn't forecasting properly in cases where a patient had received MMR prior to ART.
Change	5	Minimum Age To Start for  Risk 1-dose and Risk 2-dose series	N/A	6 months and 18 years	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 012 (Family history of altered immunocompetence) added as contraindication.	Updates made to the ACIP Best Practice Guidelines for Immunization.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Equivalent Series Group for 2-dose and Risk 2-dose series	1, 3	N/A	Because the standard series can be completed with a single dose (if the patient is over the age of 19 years) the standard and risk series are not equivalent.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Version	3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added risk indication series	To provide support for underlying conditions which are indications for vaccination beyond the standard schedule
	2	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Contraindication tab.  	To document contraindications where applicable
Change	3	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Conditional Skip for the second dose of the 2-dose series	Adult patients are fully protected from Mumps with a single dose of MMR vaccine.
Change	4	Immunity	SNOMED codes were defined for each concept.	Immunity concepts now point to coded observations (which are mapped to SNOMED in schedule supporting data)	Coded observations are used consistently in the antigen supporting data.
Change	5	General Update	N/A	Added Inadvertent Vaccine	Some vaccines, when administered, should be immediately corrected.
Change	6	General Update	From Most Recent (CVX)	From Most Recent (CVX List)	Updated to allow multiple CVX codes to be documented as part of the From Most Recent interval type

Version	2.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All doses - Interval	n/a	Added Interval Priority Skip	To determine, if applicable, when an interval override should be used.
Change	2	General Update	Removed Skip Dose, Conditional Need, and Substitute Dose concepts	Added Conditional Skip concept	To better align with current ACIP recommendations. 

Version	2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Added 2015 Childhood and Adult Immunization Schedules  to the Resources area.	To provide current ACIP Immunization recommendations for Persons Aged 0 through 18 and Adults aged 19 years and older.
	2	General Update	N/A	Added Immunity tab.  	To document evidence of immunity where applicable.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.

FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for mumps?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/mmr.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about mumps?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp	n/a
FAQs	Why does the dose for the risk series for travelers under the age of 12 months not count towards the standard series?	Children who received MMR vaccine before age 12 months should be considered potentially susceptible to rubella and should be revaccinated with 2 doses of MMR vaccine.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6204a1.htm	The risk series and standard series are in different series groups. Even if the risk series is completed, the full 2-dose standard series is required.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Vaccines	Vaccine Type (CVX)	Preferable Age Range	Allowable Age Range	Trade Name (MVX)	Volume (ml)	Status	Notes
Vaccines	meningococcal B, recombinant (162)	≥10 yrs	≥10 yrs-4 d	Trumenba (PFR)	0.5	Active
Vaccines	meningococcal B, OMV (163)	≥10 yrs	≥10 yrs-4 d	Bexsero (NOV)	0.5	Active
Vaccines	meningococcal B, unspecified (164)	Not Preferred	≥10 yrs			Inactive	Bexsero and Trumenba are not interchangeable but ACIP recommendations do allow for limited acceptance of the "unspecified" vaccine code.
Vaccines	meningococcal, unknown serogroups (167)	Not Preferred	Not Allowed			Inactive	This CVX is intended for use when any one of the meningococcal vaccines is recorded and there is no information about which serogroups (A, C, W, Y or B) are protected against.
Vaccines	meningococcal polysaccharide (MenACWY-TT conjugate), (MenB), PF (316)	≥10 yrs to < 26 yrs	≥10 yrs-4d to < 26 yrs	Penbraya (PFR)	0.5	Active

Meningococcal B risk 2-dose series MenB-4C PSP	2-dose series for Bexsero (MenB-4C) which is used only for healthy adolescents and young adults who are not at increased risk for meningococcal disease, but seek protection.

Meningococcal B risk 2-dose series MenB-FHbp PSP	2-dose series for Trumenba (MenB-FHbp) which is used only for healthy adolescents and young adults who are not at increased risk for meningococcal disease, but seek protection.

Meningococcal B risk 2-dose series MenB-4C IC	2-dose series for Bexsero (MenB-4C) which is used only for patients with increased risk.

Meningococcal B risk 3-dose series MenB-FHbp IC	3-dose series for Trumenba (MenB-FHbp) which is used only for patients with increased risk.
changeHistory:
Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Vaccine Contraindication 118 -> New Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX 316 (Penbraya) to the existing Vaccine Contraindication 118 (allergic reaction to tetanus toxoid)	Included as a contraindication in the 2024 yearly schedule

Version	4.51	Publication Date: 11/20/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose MenB-4C PSP -> Indications -> New Administrative Guidance	A MenB vaccine series may be administered to adolescents and young adults to provide short-term protection against most strains of serogroup B meningococcal disease. The preferred age for MenB vaccination is 16-18 years (recommendation Category B).	ACIP recommends a MenB vaccine series for persons aged 16-23 years on the basis of shared clinical decision-making to provide short-term protection against most strains of serogroup B meningococcal disease. The preferred age for MenB vaccination is 16-18 years.	Previous language was dated. Updated language is from the currently published MMWR.
Change	2	Risk 2-dose MenB-4Hbp PSP -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	Penbraya (MenABCWY - Pfizer) may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are indicated at the same visit.	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same visit.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose MenB-4Hbp PSP -> Indications -> New Administrative Guidance	A MenB vaccine series may be administered to adolescents and young adults to provide short-term protection against most strains of serogroup B meningococcal disease. The preferred age for MenB vaccination is 16-18 years (recommendation Category B).	ACIP recommends a MenB vaccine series for persons aged 16-23 years on the basis of shared clinical decision-making to provide short-term protection against most strains of serogroup B meningococcal disease. The preferred age for MenB vaccination is 16-18 years.	Previous language was dated. Updated language is from the currently published MMWR.
Change	4	Risk 2-dose MenB-4Hbp PSP -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable and Allowable Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX code 316 (MenABCWY)	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same clinical visit.
Change	5	Risk 2-dose MenB-4Hbp PSP -> Dose 2 -> New Allowable Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX code 316 (MenABCWY)	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same clinical visit. Note this was not added as a preferable vaccine for this dose as it is highly unlikely a patient would need both MenACWY and MenB at this visit (for this series). This was a point of discussion during ACIP and not moved forward during voting.
Change	6	Risk 3-dose MenB-4Hbp IR -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	Penbraya (MenABCWY - Pfizer) may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are indicated at the same visit.	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same visit.
Change	7	Risk 3-dose MenB-4Hbp IR -> Dose 1, 3, 4, 5 -> New Preferable and Allowable Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX code 316 (MenABCWY)	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same clinical visit. Note this was not added to dose 2 which is 4 weeks after dose 1. MenABCWY has a 6 month interval between dose 1 and dose 2.

Version	4.4	Publication Date: 01/06/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose MenB-4C PSP -> Select Patient Series -> Minimum Age to Start	10 years	16 years	This was incorrectly set at 10 years. It should be set to 16 years to align with the lowest indication begin age.
Change	2	Risk 2-dose MenB-4C PSP -> Dose 1 -> Age	10 years - 4 days 10 years 10 years	10 years - 4 days 16 years 16 years	This was incorrectly set at 10 years. It should be set to 16 years to align with the lowest indication begin age. The absolute minimum age remains at 10 years - 4 days to account for any possible earlier administrations of MenB.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose MenB-FHbp PSP -> Dose 1 -> Age	10 years - 4 days 10 years 10 years	10 years - 4 days 16 years 16 years	This was incorrectly set at 10 years. It should be set to 16 years to align with the lowest indication begin age. The absolute minimum age remains at 10 years - 4 days to account for any possible earlier administrations of MenB.

Version	4.14
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Both Patient Seeks Protection Risk Series -> Dose 2 -> Minimum Age & Earliest Recommended Age	N/A	16 years	Per updated clinical guidance the second dose should be forecasted no sooner than 16 years old.
Change	2	Both Patient Seeks Protection Risk Series -> Dose 2 -> Absolute Minimum Age	N/A	10 years - 4 days	Per updated clinical guidance the second dose should be forecasted no sooner than 16 years old, but if that dose is administered prior 16 years old it can be considered valid (provided other rules are met).

Version	4.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Patient Seeks Protection Risk Series	N/A	Added new indication for Patient seeks Meningococcal B protection (177)	Existing "Patient Seeks Protection" code (001) remains, but that applies to multiple diseases, this code is specific to Meningococcal B.

Version	4.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Increased Risk Series	2 and 3 dose series with no boosters	Both series now have two extra doses for those who remain at increased risk	The first extra dose is a 1 year booster followed by a repeating booster every 2-3 years per ACIP 2020 yearly harmonized schedule.

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Series Revamp	3 Series existed all within the same series group. One for Bexsero and two for Trumenba (2-dose and 3-dose	2 series groups have been created each containing 2 series for a total of 4 series.   - The first series group is for Patient Seeks Protection and contains a 2-dose series for Bexsero and 2-dose series for Trumenba.  - The second series group is for all other increased risk conditions and contains a 2-dose series for Bexsero and a 3-dose series for Trumenba	This is a technical correction where under specific circumstances the single series group structure in version 4.0 would yield the incorrect evaluation and forecast.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose MenB-4C and Risk 3-dose MenB-FHbp series	N/A	Added historical recommendations for doses 2 and 3 intervals	Absolute minimum intervals were added with the May 19 2017 MMWR.
Change	4	Minimum Age To Start for all Risk series	N/A	10 years or 16 years	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Version	3.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Absolute Minimum Interval for  Dose 3 in the 3-dose series	6 months - 4 days	0 days	CDC has clarified that there is no longer a required interval between doses 1 and 3 in the 3-dose series for the purpose of Evaluation. Forecasting is still recommended at 6 months from dose 1.

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	First Preferable Interval for Dose 2 of the Risk 2-dose MenB-FHbp series and Dose 3 of the Risk-3 dose MenB-FHbp series	4 weeks	4 months	Correction of an error in the original supporting data
Change	2	Final Dose in all three series	N/A	meningococcal B, unspecified (164)	CDC has clarified that the "unspecified" CVX code is acceptable for the final dose of any given series.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Absolute Minimum Interval for Dose 2 and Dose 3 in all series	0 days,  4 weeks, 6 months	4 weeks - 4 days or 6 months - 4 days	Latest ACIP MMWR defines different minimum intervals.   https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/pdfs/mm6619a6.pdf

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose MenB-FHbp Series	N/A	New 2-dose series added	ACIP recommendations now allow for a 2-dose series for Trumenba for healthy patients not at increased risk for Meningococcal disease.
Change	2	Risk 3-dose MenB-FHbp Series	N/A	New Conditional Skip logic for Dose 2	Ask the Experts clarifies under what conditions the second dose in the 3-dose series can be skipped.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for meningococcal B?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/mening.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about meningococcal B?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_b.asp	n/a
FAQs	Why is Trumenba not listed as an allowable vaccine for Bexsero and vice versa?	The two vaccines are not considered interchangeable and full series of one vaccine or the other is necessary to be considered fully protected.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/wk/mm6441.pdf	Separate series are maintained for the two difference vaccines.
FAQs	HIV infection is a risk indication for meningococcal ACWY, why is it not part of the supporting data for meningococcal B as well?	Meningococcal B is not routinely recommended for adults with HIV infection, because meningococcal disease in this population is caused primarily by serogroups C, W, and Y	https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6605e2.htm?s_cid=mm6605e2_e	HIV infection is not an indication for Meningococcal B.
FAQs	Why do the final doses in the 2-dose MenB-FHbp series contain two intervals?	If a second dose of Trumenba is given at an interval of less than 6 months, a third dose should be given at least 6 months after the first dose; the minimum interval between the second (invalid) dose and third administered dose is 4 months. 	https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf	Potential intervals are given relative to the valid first dose (6 months) and the immediate preceding dose (which could be either the valid first dose or an invalid second dose).
FAQs	Why is the unspecified meningococcal B vaccine (CVX 164) only allowed for the final dose in a series?	Guidance from CDC subject matter experts allows for acceptance of the unspecified vaccine only for the final dose in a series.	n/a	n/a
FAQs	There is no required interval between doses 1 and 3 of the 3-dose series, so why does the third dose document such an interval?	Guidance from CDC subject matter experts indicates that for evaluation purposes, there is no required interval between doses 1 and 3, but for forecasting purposes, dose 3 should still be recommended for 6 months after dose 1.	n/a	The third dose includes an interval between doses 1 and 3 but the Absolute Minimum Interval is 0 days to allow any dose that meets the interval between doses 2 and 3 to be considered valid. The Earliest Recommended Interval remains 6 months.
FAQs	How can the supporting data be used to implement the Category B recommendation for otherwise healthy young adults aged 16-23 years?	Once support of risk series is implemented, by assigning an indication of "Patient seeks protection (001)" to all individuals of the appropriate age, vaccination against Meningococcal B will be recommended.	n/a	n/a

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Meningococcal ACWY 2-dose series	Standard 2-dose series which allows for skipping the first dose if not administered by age 16 years.

Risk Start 2-23 months	Risk series for patients initiating vaccination from 2 months though 23 months of age.

Meningococcal ACWY risk Hib-MenCY-TT 4-dose series	4-dose Hib combined series for patients at increased risk

Meningococcal ACWY risk 2-dose series	2-dose series for patients at increased risk over the age of 2 years.

Meningococcal ACWY risk 1-dose series	1-dose series for patients at increased risk over the age of 2 years.
changeHistory:
Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> removed Vaccine Contraindications	n/a	Removed all contraindications specific to CVX 114 (Menactra)	Menactra has been discontinued.
Change	2	Contraindications -> Vaccine Contraindication 118 -> New Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX 316 (Penbraya) to the existing Vaccine Contraindication 118 (allergic reaction to tetanus toxoid)	Included as a contraindication in the 2024 yearly schedule
Change	3	All Series -> Removed Preferable Vaccines	n/a	Removed all Preferable Vaccines where CVX 114 (Menactra) was listed as preferable	Menactra has been discontinued. No adjustments were made to allowable vaccines or skip conditions to support proper evaluation of historical records.
Change	4	Risk Series -> Removed Administrative Guidance	If MenACWY-D is used, it should be administered at least 4 weeks after completion of all PCV doses.	Removed	Menactra has been discontinued so this administrative guidance is no longer needed.
Change	5	2-dose -> Dose 2 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval to forecast a 6 month spacing if Penbraya was administered as dose 1.	Penbraya spacing is recommended at 6 months. However, if the second dose is administered on or after 8 weeks - 4 days it can be considered a valid dose of ACWY per SME guidance.
Change	6	Risk 2-dose -> Dose 2 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval to forecast a 6 month spacing if Penbraya was administered as dose 1.	Penbraya spacing is recommended at 6 months. However, if the second dose is administered on or after 8 weeks - 4 days it can be considered a valid dose of ACWY per SME guidance.

Version	4.51	Publication Date: 11/20/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	2-dose -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	Penbraya (MenABCWY - Pfizer) may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are indicated at the same visit.	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same visit.
Change	2	2-dose -> Dose 1 -> New Allowable Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX code 316 (MenABCWY)	This vaccine may be used when both MenACWY and MenB are recommended at the same clinical visit. Note this was not added as a preferable vaccine for this dose as it is highly unlikely a patient would need both MenACWY and MenB at this visit (for this series). Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Start 2-23 month series -> Dose 2 & 3 -> Conditional Skip -> Condition ID	n/a	1	Condition ID should always be populated if a skip condition exists. 

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk < 7 month 4-dose series and Risk > 7 month 2-dose series	n/a	Series removed	These series were removed and consolidated into a single Risk start at 2-23 month series.
Change	2	Risk Start 2-23 month series	n/a	New series created	This series harmonizes two existing series (Risk < 7 monts and Risk > 7 months). Additionally, improvements were made to catch-up dosing when a patient starts late or falls behind.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose -> Indication -> HIV Infection (186) -> Indication Begin Age 	2 months	2 years	This was an existing copy/paste error and should have been 2 years. HIV infection below 2 years is addressed in the Risk start at 2-23 months series.
Change	4	Risk 2-dose -> Dose 1 -> Absolute Minimum Age	2 months - 4 days	2 years - 4 days	This was an existing copy/paste error and should have been 2 years. Doses below 2 years are addressed in the Risk start at 2-23 months series.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

MenQuadfi should have been included initially.
Change	3	Risk < 7 month, Risk >7 month, and Risk 2-dose series -> Indications	HIV/AIDS codes (154 and 155)	Removed	Removed and replace with new code for HIV Infection (Code 186) per MMWR language
Change	4	Risk < 7 month, Risk >7 month, and Risk 2-dose series -> Indications	n/a	HIV Infection (186)	Added new indication per MMWR language. This single code replaces codes 154 and 155 which included immunocompromising severity and AIDS which aren't relevant for Meningicoccal vaccination.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

Version	2.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All doses - Interval	n/a	Added Interval Priority Skip	To determine, if applicable, when an interval override should be used.
	2	General Update	Removed Skip Dose, Conditional Need, and Substitute Dose concepts	Added Conditional Skip concept	To better align with current ACIP recommendations. 
Change	3	Allowable Vaccine - Dose 2, Vaccine Type (CVX)	Meningococcal, MPSV4 (32)	Removed	To better align with ACIP Meningococcal  immunization recommendations. 

Version	2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Added 2015 Childhood and Adult Immunization Schedules  to the Resources area.	To provide current ACIP Immunization recommendations for Persons Aged 0 through 18 and Adults aged 19 years and older.
	2	General Update	N/A	Added Immunity Tab.  	To document evidence of immunity where applicable.

Version	1.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	MCV Standard Series    -> Dose 2       -> Absolute Minimum Age	10 years + 8 weeks - 4 days	16 years - 4 days	Per EIPB guidance, the second dose must be administered on or after the 16 year - 4 day mark.
Change	2	MCV Standard Series    -> Dose 2       -> Minimum Age	11 years + 8 weeks	16 years	Per EIPB guidance, the second dose must be forecasted on or after the 16 year mark.

Version	1.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Minimum age	2 years	2 months	The minimum age for Menveo was lowered from 2 years down to 2 months.  Accordingly, the unspecified vaccine codes were lowered to 2 months for consistency purposes.

Version	1.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccines on dose 1 and 2 of standard series	CVX 136 was not present	Added CVX 136 to the list of allowable vaccines.	This was missing previously from the list of allowable vaccines.

Version	1.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 1 Absolute Minimum Age	11 Years - 4 days	10 Years	The absolute minimum age for dose 1 of MCV was lowered to validate doses administered starting at 10 years based on SME expectation that doses given at 10 years (for states with school law requiring 1 dose to enter 5th grade) should count towards the 2 dose 11 year standard series.  This is for evaluation purposes only.  It is not to be used for forecasting.
Change	2	Dose 2 Absolute Minimum Age	11 Years + 8 weeks - 4 days	10 Years + 8 weeks - 4 days	The absolute minimum age for dose 2 of MCV was lowered to validate doses in conjunction with the first change.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Absolute Minimum Age and Minimum Age: Dose 1	2 Years - 4 days and 2 Years respectively	11 Years - 4 days and 11 Years respectively	High Risk is out of scope, but was implied by the 2 Year values.  This series is strictly for the 2-dose adolescent series currently in-scope.
Change	4	Maximum Age on Dose 2	No Value	22 Years	For non-high risk patients, dose 2 of MCV is only recommended through 21 years (less than 22 years).  Since high risk is out of scope, then 22 years was added to drop forecasting once the patient turns 22 and hasn't received their 2nd dose.
faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for meningococcal ACWY?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/mening.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about meningococcal ACWY?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_meningococcal_acwy.asp	n/a
FAQs	Why do all the risk series have an additional 2 doses at the end of the series?	The final 2 doses of the risk series are booster doses. If the patient is younger than age 7 years when the primary series is completed, then the first booster dose should be given with a 3 year interval followed by boosters every 5 years afterwards. If the patient is over the age of 7 years when the primary series is completed, then the first booster should be given with a 5 year interval and every 5 years afterwards.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/mening.html	The second to last dose has an interval of 3 years and Conditional Skip logic that allows the dose to be skipped if the primary series was completed after the age of 7 years. Because only a single booster dose with a 3 year interval is required, this dose is not marked as a Recurring Dose. The final dose is a recurring dose with an interval of 5 years.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html
