changeHistory:
Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Removed Contraindication	Immunocompromised (003)	Removed	This was removed as it is too broad and includes all forms of immunocompromise (mild-to-severe).
Change	2	Contraindications -> New Contraindication	n/a	Added Severe Immunocompromise (246)	This was added as a better classification which results in a contraindication.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose -> New Indication	n/a	Added new Indication "Household and close contacts of immunocompromised persons" (Code 073)	This was present in Measles, but missing in Mumps and Rubella

Version	4.39	Publication Date: 12/13/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New PRIORIX vaccine	n/a	n/a	PRIORIX is the same CVX code as M-M-R II (03) with the same contraindications and is interchangeable in use. No changes were made to any Immunity, Contraindications, or Series tabs. Priorix was added to the overview tab.

Version	4.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 003 (Immunocompromised) was added as a contraindication	This is an existing PHINVADS code exchanged in HL7 (VXC27) and results in a contraindication.

Version	4.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose Interval on Dose 2 Recommended Intervals	3 years and 6 years	4 weeks and n/a	This was incorrectly carried forward from the standard series. Patients at increased risk are recommended to receive their next dose 28 days apart.

Version	4.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 168 (Chemotherapy) added as a contraindication	This has been a contraindication for quite some time in published recommendations, but was missing in CDSi.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose Series Indication updates	Code 026 (ART) was included	Removed code 026 (ART)	This was removed as a new series was created for ART-specific recommendations. See next change for further details.
Change	4	New Risk 2-dose ART Series	N/A	Created a new Series for patients who undergo antiviral therapy (ART)	Previously ART was included in the Risk 2-dose series, but wasn't forecasting properly in cases where a patient had received MMR prior to ART.
Change	5	Minimum Age To Start for Risk 1-dose and Risk 2-dose series	N/A	6 months and 18 years	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 012 (Family history of altered immunocompetence) added as contraindication.	Updates made to the ACIP Best Practice Guidelines for Immunization.
Change	2	Administrative Guidance	N/A	Guidance added on administering a 3rd dose in outbreak scenarios.	ACIP has published new guidance on administering a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine in an outbreak scenario.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Equivalent Series Group for 2-dose and Risk 2-dose series	1, 3	N/A	Because the standard series can be completed with a single dose (if the patient is over the age of 19 years) the standard and risk series are not equivalent.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Version	3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added risk indication series	To provide support for underlying conditions which are indications for vaccination beyond the standard schedule
	2	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Contraindication tab.  	To document contraindications where applicable
Change	3	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Conditional Skip for the second dose of the 2-dose series	Adult patients are fully protected from Mumps with a single dose of MMR vaccine.
Change	4	Immunity	SNOMED codes were defined for each concept.	Immunity concepts now point to coded observations (which are mapped to SNOMED in schedule supporting data)	Coded observations are used consistently in the antigen supporting data.
Change	5	General Update	N/A	Added Inadvertent Vaccine	Some vaccines, when administered, should be immediately corrected.
Change	6	General Update	From Most Recent (CVX)	From Most Recent (CVX List)	Updated to allow multiple CVX codes to be documented as part of the From Most Recent interval type

Version	2.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All doses - Interval	n/a	Added Interval Priority Skip	To determine, if applicable, when an interval override should be used.
Change	2	General Update	Removed Skip Dose, Conditional Need, and Substitute Dose concepts	Added Conditional Skip concept	To better align with current ACIP recommendations. 

Version	2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Added 2015 Childhood and Adult Immunization Schedules  to the Resources area.	To provide current ACIP Immunization recommendations for Persons Aged 0 through 18 and Adults aged 19 years and older.
	2	General Update	N/A	Added Immunity Tab.  	To document evidence of immunity where applicable.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for mumps?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/mmr.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about mumps?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp	n/a
FAQs	Why does the dose for the risk series for travelers under the age of 12 months not count towards the standard series?	Children who received MMR vaccine before age 12 months should be considered potentially susceptible to rubella and should be revaccinated with 2 doses of MMR vaccine.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6204a1.htm	The risk series and standard series are in different series groups. Even if the risk series is completed, the full 2-dose standard series is required.
FAQs	Why is a 3rd dose of mumps vaccine not present in any series?	ACIP has released recommendations for a 3rd dose in an outbreak scenario. We expect that the management of individuals at risk during an outbreak will be managed through processes distinct from the typical CDS engine and therefore is only present in the CDSi supporting data as Administrative Guidance.	n/a	The intent of the ACIP recommendation is present as Administrative Guidance in each series.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

Resources	JYNNEOS recommendations - https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/71/wr/mm7122e1.htm
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Risk More Virulent 2-dose series	2-dose series with booster in 2-3 years for those who are in contact with more virulent orthopoxvirus.

Risk Less Virulent 2-dose series	2-dose series with booster in 10 years for those who are in contact with less virulent orthopoxvirus.

Risk pre-exposure 2-dose series	2-dose risk-based pre-exposure series for those at increased risk for mpox disease.

Risk Post Exposure 2-dose series	2-dose post-exposure series to support the mpox Public Health Emergency

series:
Series Name	Risk more virulent 2-dose series
Target Disease	Orthopoxvirus
Vaccine Group	Orthopoxvirus
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	Persons who previously received ACAM2000 should decide before their next booster dose whether to receive ACAM2000 or JYNNEOS. Persons who transition to receiving JYNNEOS boosters are expected to continue receiving JYNNEOS boosters and to not revert to ACAM2000; in addition, the frequency of booster doses should correspond to the vaccine used for boosters. For example, persons who previously received ACAM2000 every 3 years because of work with more virulent orthopoxviruses might decide to change to JYNNEOS when their next booster dose is due; in these cases, subsequent JYNNEOS booster doses should be administered every 2 years.
Administrative Guidance	Evidence of a take is often used as a marker of successful vaccination after ACAM2000. Because JYNNEOS is a replication-deficient vaccine, vaccination with JYNNEOS does not produce a take
Administrative Guidance	When vaccination is used for prevention of mpox in persons with HIV infection, JYNNEOS is preferred over ACAM2000.

Series Name	Risk post-exposure 2-dose series
Target Disease	Orthopoxvirus
Vaccine Group	Orthopoxvirus
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	CDC recommends initiating vaccination within 4 days following the date of exposure for the best chance to prevent on set of the disease. If initiated between 4 and 14 days following the date of exposure, vaccination might be less effective. Benefits might still outweigh risks when administering more than 14 days after exposure in some clinical situations (e.g., severely immunosuppressed)
Administrative Guidance	JYNNEOS vaccine can be administered through 2 different regimens. Please see https://www.cdc.gov/poxvirus/mpox/interim-considerations/jynneos-vaccine.html for more details.
Administrative Guidance	Prior to administration in people younger than age 6 months, clinicians should first contact their jurisdictional health department (https://resources.cste.org/epiafterhours). Jurisdictional health departments can facilitate consultation with CDC if needed.
Administrative Guidance	In response to the current outbreak, vaccines and other medical measures should be given to eligible people who were previously vaccinated against smallpox.
Administrative Guidance	Evidence of a take is often used as a marker of successful vaccination after ACAM2000. Because JYNNEOS is a replication-deficient vaccine, vaccination with JYNNEOS does not produce a take
Administrative Guidance	When vaccination is used for prevention of mpox in persons with HIV infection, JYNNEOS is preferred over ACAM2000.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Standard Series	This series is the standard DTaP/Tdap series.
	Doses 1-5: Standard DTaP doses for childern < 7 years. It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered on or after 4 years of age.
Pertussis standard series	Dose 6-8: Tdap catch-up doses. If needed, a patients will receive at most one of these doses.
Pertussis standard series	Dose 9-10: Tdap at age 11 years and over. If needed, a patient will receive at most on the these doses.

Start at 12 months Series	This series has the same structure as the standard series, but is for patients who receive their first dose on or after 12 months of age. 
	Doses 1-5: Standard DTaP doses for childern < 7 years. It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered on or after 4 years of age.
Pertussis standard series	Dose 6-8: Tdap catch-up doses. If needed, a patients will receive at most one of these doses.
Pertussis standard series	Dose 9-10: Tdap at age 11 years and over. If needed, a patient will receive at most on the these doses.

Pertussis risk 1-dose series	Risk based 1-dose series for persons at increased risk
changeHistory:
Version	4.45	Publication Date: 07/27/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Standard and Start at 12 Months Series -> Doses 1 - 6 -> Vaccine Count by Age Skip Conditions 	01;11;20;22;50;102;106;107;110;115;120;130;132;146;170	01;11;20;22;50;102;106;107;110;115;120;130;132;146;170; 198	CVX 198 was missing and added to the list of CVX codes. For harmonization purposes, CVX 11 was missing on dose 6 and was added. Dose 6 skip condition requires the dose to be valid - which 11 never will be - but adding this will allow for consistent management in the future. It won't have any impact on skipping.
Change	2	Standard and Start at 12 Months Series -> Dose 1-5 -> 6 doses by 7 years skip condition	6 weeks - 4 days	n/a	The 6 doses by 7 years rule includes doses that occurred before 6 weeks of age.
Change	3	Standard and Start at 12 Months Series -> Dose 7 -> Forecast Skip Condition -> Set Logic	n/a	OR	This was missing and could lead to varied intrepretations by implementers.

Version	4.41	Publication Date: 03/07/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 1-dose -> Dose 1 -> Preferable Interval	Abs Min Int: n/a Min Int: n/a	Abs Min Int: 0 days Min Int: 27 weeks	Fully specifying these values will help enable an earliest date on the forecast as well as avoid validating Tdap which occurred prior to onset of pregnancy.

Version	4.23
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Standard and Start at 12 Months Series -> Dose 9 -> Interval Priority Flag	n/a	override	ACIP recommends Tdap at age 11-12 even if a person had received Tdap prior to age 10 years. This override ensures priority is given to Pertussis (Tdap) at age 11-12.

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Standard and Start at 12 Months -> Doses 7-8 -> Conditional Skips	1 conditional skip with a context of Both	2 Conditional Skips. 1 with context of Both has been adjusted slightly. A Second with a context of Forecast has been added	ACIP recommendations were updated to allow either Tdap or Td to be administered when only Td is indicated but isn't required. The updated skips will allow Tdap to be validated (if administered) or skipped (if only Td is administered).

Version	4.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Standard and Start at 12 Months -> Doses 2 - 5 -> Interval Priority	n/a	override	This will ensure a proper forecast in rare cases where a patient received a DT product, but should have received a DTaP product.
Change	2	Start at 12 Months -> Select Patient Series -> Series Preference	1	2	This value should have been 2 when this series was created in version 4.3. The standard series (default) has a value of 1 and this catch-up series should be of lower preference much like it is in diphtheria and tetanus supporting data.

Version	4.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

Change	2	Vaccine Contraindications in Contraindications tab	n/a	Added new CVX (198) to existing Vaccine-Specific Contraindications	Contraindications are specific to pertussis-containing vaccines.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

Change	2	Allowable Vaccine Maximum Age across all doses	All DTP containing entries had a maximum age of 19 years	Changed all entries to N/A	Per an Ask the Experts FAQ, while this is  not preferred, these can be counted as a Td or Tdap vaccination if inadvertently administered regardless of age.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 6 Skip Dose Trigger Age	11 years	removed 11 years and set to "n/a"	Dose 6 is the catch-up dose for Tdap when DTaP was not fully administered.  This dose are still recommended for completion past 11 years so it should not have been skipped.  Removing the skip dose trigger age allows this recommendation to be met.
Change	2	Doses 1 - 5 Skip Dose Trigger Doses Administered	N/A	Added support for 6 doses by 7 years in DTaP	A 1991 MMWR statement for DTP recommends a maximum of 6 doses prior to 7 years of age regardless of validity.

Version	1.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 4 Allowable Interval	not populated.  New logical component in version 1.7	4 months	4 months, which is acknowledged as an allowable interval was previously specified in the "Absolute Minimum Interval" on the interval logical component.  This worked in all cases except when spacing from a not valid interval.  The new allowable interval fixes this and allows the 4 month interval even from an invalid dose.

Version	1.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on all doses	All DTaP containing  vaccines had a vaccine type end age of 11 years	Changed to 19 years for all DTaP containing vaccines	Per 2014 Childhood/Adolescent Harmonized schedule - DTaP can be inadvertently administered through 18 years (less than 19 years) and be counted as the adolescent Tdap booster dose.

Version	1.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on last dose	Only Tdap was an allowable vaccine.	Carried all allowable vaccines from the previous dose down to the last dose.	Since the last dose could actually be administered at 7 years old, an allowable administration of DTaP and other allowable vaccines in the previous dose could still be administered and be considered valid.
Change	2	Skip Dose on Last Dose in Series	N/A	Added a Trigger Target Dose value of 6 to properly skip the last dose if target dose 6 was satisfied	Tdap is recommended for a one time administration after 7 years, but can be either recommended at 7 or 11 years depending upon DTaP administrations.  Previously, the supporting data would recommend a dose at 7 AND at 11.  This allows for skipping the 11 year recommendation if the child is recommended and receives a dose between 7 through 10 years.  Either dose 6 or 7 must be satisfied, but not both.
Change	3	Interval on Last Dose	Interval was specified	Removed Interval on 11 year Adolescent dose	A child who is "fully vaccinated" for DTaP by age 7 years is to be recommended for Tdap at age 11 years without regard to interval.  Similarly, the adolescent dose of Tdap can be administered without regard to interval from the last DTaP dose.  This is not the case, however, when the child enters age 7 years and is not fully vaccinated for DTaP and this is addressed in dose 6 in the pertussis series.

Version	1.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Latest Recommended Interval on Dose 7	N/A	10 years + 4 weeks	Based on clarification from NIPInfo.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferrable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Substitute Dose	Missing conditions	Added substitutions to dose 6 for a child who is up-to-date to properly substitute the catch-up dose	A child who is up-to-date at age 7, doesn't need to go through the catch-up dose #6.  This was missing in version 1.0 and forcing the child through the catch-up dose.
Change	4	Catch-up Doses 6 Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals	Values not specified	Added Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals to match the Earliest Recommended Age and Earliest Recommended Intervals for each dose.	These were empty before which resulted in a forecast with no Past Due Date.  Since the child is in catch-up at this point, the Past Due Date should align with the Recommended Date.
Change	5	Age Values on Dose 7	Values partially specified	Absolute Minimum Age: 7 years Minimum Age: 11 Years Earliest Recommended Age: 11 Years Latest Recommended Age: 13 Years	There were some age values on the recurring dose which resulted in the 11 year dose for a child who was up-to-date with childhood DTaP as incorrect.  The new ages help align D, T, and P forecasts.

FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for pertussis?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/dtap.html  http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/tdap-td.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about pertussis?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_per.asp	n/a
FAQs	Is there a maximum number of doses of DTaP a child should receive?	ACIP recommends that children receive no more than 6 doses of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids (e.g., DT, DTaP, DTP) before the seventh birthday because of concern about adverse reactions, primarily local reactions	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_tet.asp	Each of the first 5 doses in the standard series has Conditional Skip logic indicating that receiving 6 or more doses before the age of the 7 is sufficient grounds for skipping the dose.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

SERIES GROUP 1 | STANDARD

Pneumococcal 4-dose series	The standard series is for children who start roughly on time (before 12 months) and then either follow the schedule or become lapse.   
Pneumococcal 4-dose series	Key trigger points are 12 months and 24 months where the number of doses required are reduced if not already received. 
Pneumococcal 4-dose series	For persons having received a complete series consisting only of PCV7 a subsequent dose of PCV13 or PCV15 is required.

Pneumococcal dose 2 at 7 months series	If the second dose of PCV is administered on or after 7 months and before 12 months, the catch-up recommendations are to receive a final dose at 12 mo and 8 weeks.
Pneumococcal dose 2 at 7 months series	For persons having received a complete series consisting only of PCV7 a subsequent dose of PCV13 or PCV15 is required.

Pneumococcal start at 12 months series	The start at 12 mo series is for children who start on or after 12 months, but before 24 months.  This series requires a second dose 8 weeks after dose 1.
Pneumococcal start at 12 months series	For persons having received a complete series consisting only of PCV7 a subsequent dose of PCV13 or PCV15 is required.

Pneumococcal start at 24 months series	The start at 24 mo series is for children who start on or after 24 months.  If the single dose is PCV7, a subsequent dose of PCV13 or PCV15 is required.

SERIES GROUP 2 | RISK

Pneumococcal risk 2-5 years CMC PCV-PCV-PPSV series	A 3-dose series for children 2 through 5 years at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions, CSF leaks, or cochlear implants.

Pneumococcal risk 2-5 years CMC PCV-PPSV-PCV series	A 3-dose series for children 2 through 5 years at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions, CSF leaks, or cochlear implants.

Pneumococcal risk 2-5 years CMC PPSV-PCV-PCV series	A 3-dose series for children 2 through 5 years at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions, CSF leaks, or cochlear implants.

Pneumococcal risk 2-5 years 4-dose series	A 4-dose series for children 2 through 5 years at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 6-18 years 2-dose PCV-PPSV	2-dose series for persons 6 through 18 years of age at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions, CSF leaks, or cochlear implants.

Pneumococcal risk 6-18 years 2-dose PPSV-PCV	2-dose series for persons 6 through 18 years of age at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions, CSF leaks, or cochlear implants.

Pneumococcal risk 6-18 years IC PCV-PPSV-PPSV	3-dose series for persons 6 through 18 years of age at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 6-18 years IC PPSV-PCV-PPSV	3-dose series for persons 6 through 18 years of age at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 6-18 years IC PPSV-PPSV-PCV	3-dose series for persons 6 through 18 years of age at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years CMC PCV-PPSV	2-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years CMC PPSV-PCV	2-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to chronic medical conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years CSF CI PCV-PPSV	2-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to CSF leaks or cochelar implants.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years CSF CI PPSV-PCV	2-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to CSF leaks or cochelar implants.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years IC PCV-PPSV-PPSV	3-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years IC PPSV-PCV-PPSV	3-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

Pneumococcal risk 19+ years IC PPSV-PPSV-PCV	3-dose series for persons 19+ years of age at increased risk due to immunocompromising conditions.

SERIES GROUP 3 | STANDARD 65+

Pneumococcal 65+ 2-dose PCV-PPSV23 series	Age-based recommendation for all adults aged 65+ to receive PCV followed by PPSV

Pneumococcal 65+ 2-dose PPSV23-PCV series	Aged-based recommendation for all adults aged 65+ to receive PCV if previously received PPSV

Change	1	Risk 2-5 years CMC PCV-PCV-PPSV -> Select Patiet Series -> Series Priority	E	B	With the revamp of the risk series, the Series Priorities became a little out of sorts with missing letters across series. This simply oranizes these.

Change	1	Risk Series Re-order	Previous order was: * Age 2-5 years * CMC/CSF/CI for 6+ * IC for 6+	New order is by age, then condition within age: * Age 2-5 years       - CMC/CSF/CI -> 3 series      - IC -> 1 series  * Age 6-18 years       - CMC/CSF/CI -> 2 series      - IC -> 3 series  * Age 19+ years       - CMC -> 2 series      - CSF/CI -> 2 series      - IC -> 3 series	Acronyms CMC = Chronic Medical Conditions CSF = Cerebrospinal fluid leaks CI = Cochlear Implants IC = Immunocompromised  Grouping by age and then condition better aligns with ACIP published recommendations. It creates more series (see next change), but provides a cleaner map to recommendations, closes some gaps, and creates simplified series. All series are mutually exclusive by indications, age range, and pcv/ppsv administration order to ease series selection complexities.
Change	2	New Series	n/a	4 new risk series: * Risk 6-18 yrs 2-dose PCV-PPSV * Risk 6-18 yrs IC PCV-PCV-PPSV * Risk 19+ yrs CMC PCV-PPSV * Risk 19+ yrs CMC PPSV-PCV	New age-range-specific risk series help close existing gaps regarding conditions and intervals which can be slightly different between 6-18 and 19+
Change	3	Risk 2-5 years CMC PCV-PCV-PPSV -> Indications -> Asthma (27) -> Administrative Guidance	For patients aged 2 through 5 years, asthma is only an indication for vaccination if the patient is treated with high-dose oral corticosteroid therapy.	Includes persons with moderate persistent or severe persistent asthma (regardless of high-dose oral corticosteroids use)	Language change in ACIP recommendations
Change	4	Risk 2-5 years CMC PCV-PCV-PPSV -> Dose 1, 2 -> Skip conditions -> Vaccine Count by Age -> Vaccine Type (CVX List)	133; 215; 216	109; 133; 152; 215; 216	Included unspecified formulations which are allowable vaccines in the childhood age-based series so should be included in dose counting for skipping purposes. This may happen with historical records.

Version	4.51	Publication Date: 11/20/2023

Change	5	Risk 19+ 3-dose PPSV-PCV-PPSV -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Vaccine -> Forecast Vaccine Type	Y	N	Patients within this series are recommended to receive either PPSV23 in 8 weeks (not 1 year) or PCV20 in 5 years. Version	4.44	Publication Date: 06/06/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Start at 24 Months -> Dose 1 -> New Preferable Interval	n/a	New interval	This was added as a safeguard against an edge case which was resulting in a third dose administered on or after 24 months of age, but less than 8 weeks from the previous dose incorrectly evaluating the patient's immunization history and incorrectly considering the patient complete. This ensures the final dose is at least 8 weeks removed from any previous dose.
Change	2	Risk 2-dose PCV-PPSV -> Dose 2 -> Age -> Earliest Recommended Age	6 years	n/a	This was previously "n/a", and was set to "6 years" in version 4.41 (along with Minimum Age). This resolved an issue reported when forecasting if a patient had received doses under 6 years old, but created a problem in forecasting if the patient was over 6 years old. Removing Earliest Recommended Age, but keeping Minimum Age should allow both scenarios to forecast properly.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose PCV-PPSV -> Dose 3 & 4 -> Conditional Skip -> Dose Type	Total	Valid	Skip Conditions looking for PCV15 or PCV20 should be based on previously valid doses, not previous doses regardless of validity
Change	4	Risk < 19 years 2-dose PCV-PPSV -> Dose 3 -> Conditional Skip -> Dose Type	Total	Valid	Skip Conditions looking for PCV15 or PCV20 should be based on previously valid doses, not previous doses regardless of validity
Change	5	Risk 19+ years 2-dose PCV-PPSV -> Dose 3 & 4 -> Conditional Skip -> Dose Type	Total	Valid	Skip Conditions looking for PCV15 or PCV20 should be based on previously valid doses, not previous doses regardless of validity
Change	6	Risk 3-dose PCV-PPSV-PPSV -> Dose 3, 4 & 5 -> Conditional Skip -> Dose Type	Total	Valid	Skip Conditions looking for PCV15 or PCV20 should be based on previously valid doses, not previous doses regardless of validity

Change	8	Risk 19+ 3-dose PPSV-PCV-PPSV -> Dose 3, 4 & 5 -> Conditional Skip -> Dose Type	Total	Valid	Skip Conditions looking for PCV15 or PCV20 should be based on previously valid doses, not previous doses regardless of validity

Change	11	65+ 2-dose PCV-PPSV23 -> Dose 3 & 4 -> Conditional Skip -> Dose Type	Total	Valid	Skip Conditions looking for PCV15 or PCV20 should be based on previously valid doses, not previous doses regardless of validity
Change	12	65+ 2-dose PPSV23-PCV -> Dose 3 -> Age -> Earliest Recommended Age	65 years	n/a	Removing this age allows for better support of PCV20 or PPSV23 optionality. In most cases, the recommended date will be 5 years from the most recent dose.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	65+ 2-dose PPSV23-PCV -> Dose 3 -> Preferable Interval -> Earliest Recommended Interval	1 year	5 years	Patients who are recommended a third dose can receive either a PPSV23 as early as 1 year or a PCV20 at 5 years. The minimum interval remains at 1 year while this Earliest Recommended Interval was moved out to 5 years to support the interval window.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose PCV-PPSV -> Updated Administrative Guidance	Adults who have received PCV13 but have not completed their recommended pneumococcal vaccine series with PPSV23, one dose of PCV20 may be used if PPSV23 is not available. New shared clinical decision-making recommendation.
Change	4	Risk 2-dose PCV-PPSV -> Dose 2 -> Age	Abs Min: n/a Minimum: n/a Earliest: n/a	Abs Min: 2 years - 4 days Minimum: 6 years Earliest: 6 years	Patients who received PCV13 or PCV15 before age 6 years are allowed to skip dose 1. Adding this will create a more logical forecast date of on or after 6 years.

These changes restrict the use of PPSV23 to age 65 years and above. Modifications have also been made to the age for this dose to accommodate PCV20 under 65 years of age. See previous change.

Change	3	General Update	N/A	Added 65+ PCV/PPSV series	Expanded project scope to incorporate Age-based Adult Recommendations

Version	1.9	Publication Date: 02/05/2015
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	PCV Standard Series - Maximum Age To Start	7 months - 4 days	12 months - 4 days	As noted below (release 1.3) this should have been set to 12 months - 4 days already, but was erroneously set to 7 months - 4 days.
Change	2	PCV dose 2 at 7 mo Series	N/A	New Series	An additional series was created based on the clarifications provided in the 2015 Harmonized schedule catch-up table to address the situation when the second dose is administered on or after 7 months and before 12 months.

Version	1.3	Publication Date: 11/07/2013
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	PCV Standard Series - Maximum Age To Start	N/A	12 months - 4 days	New attribute was created to improve Select Patient Series to address situations where ACIP recommendations differ based on the age of the first dose.  PCV benefits from this improvement.
Change	2	PCV Start at 12 mo Series - Maximum Age To Start	N/A	24 months - 4 days	New attribute was created to improve Select Patient Series to address situations where ACIP recommendations differ based on the age of the first dose.  PCV benefits from this improvement.
Change	3	PCV7 & PCV13 transition schedule.  Affects all Series through the addition of a new dose.	Last Dose was required to be PCV13	Revamped supporting data to allow for all valid PCV7 and then recommend subsequent dose PCV13.	The previous versions of the supporting data didn't align with the recommendations as it required the last dose to be a PCV13 when in fact, the ACIP recommendations are that at least 1 dose must be a PCV13.  If all doses (which can all be valid) are PCV7 doses, then a subsequent dose of PCV13 is indicated.  This is accomplished through the use of Conditional Need which recommends a subsequent last dose if none of the previous doses were PCV13.

Version	1.2	Publication Date: 09/19/2013
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Maximum Age all doses; all series	N/A	5 years	5 years is the latest recommended age by ACIP for healthy children.
Change	2	Earliest and Latest Recommended Age in the start at 12 mo series	N/A	12 Months	Missing values resulted in a forecast which had empty recommended and past due values.
Change	3	Earliest and Latest Recommended Age in the start at 24 mo series	N/A	24 Months	Missing values resulted in a forecast which had empty recommended and past due values.

Version	1.1	Publication Date: 06/25/2013
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Allowable Vaccine	N/A	Pneumococcal Conjugate, Unspecified Formulation (152) was added as an allowable vaccine.	New CVX
Change	4	Catch-up Recommendations	N/A	2 new series were created to better define the catch-up recommendations for PCV.  Additionally, the PCV Standard Series has modified the skip dose trigger ages.	Version 1.0 of PCV was missing a couple catch-up scenarios where a child starts on time and then becomes lapse.  Correcting these situations led to new series to address children who start late.

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for pneumococcal?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/pneumo.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about pneumococcal?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_pneumococcal_vaccines.asp	n/a
FAQs	Is one dose of PCV13, PCV15, or PCV20 required for all standard childhood series?	Yes, all standard childhood series should include at least one dose of PCV13, PCV15, or PCV20. Even if the individual completed the series with PCV7 or PCV10 (foreign available vaccine), one additional dose of PCV13, PCV15, or PCV20 is recommended.	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_pneumococcal_vaccines.asp	An additional dose of PCV13, PCV15, or PCV20 is included in each standard childhood series with Conditional Skip logic that allows it to be skipped if the individual has at least one dose of PCV13, PCV15, or PCV20.
FAQs	Why are there multiple variants of many of the series, varying only in the order in which the vaccines (PCV and PPSV23) are given?	Many recommendations for at risk and elderly individuals require doses of both PCV and PPSV23. While PCV is recommended first, any order if valid. The current structure of the supporting data is such that multiple series must be defined.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/pneumo.html	Multiple series are created.
FAQs	If the ACIP recommendation is not to give PCV and PPSV vaccines simultaneously, why is the absolute minimum interval between these two vaccines often 0 days?	An Ask the Experts question clarified that if PCV and PPSV23 are inadvertently given at the same visit, neither dose needs to be repeated.	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_pneumococcal_vaccines.asp	0 days is the correct absolute minimum interval
FAQs	In October 2022 ACIP voted to approve the use of PCV20 following PCV13 administration. Where can I find more information?	A dedicated resource on scenarios and options can be found online here: www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/pneumo/downloads/pneumo-vaccine-timing.pdf	www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/pneumo/downloads/pneumo-vaccine-timing.pdf	These scenarios have been incorporated as much as possible. Sometimes option A or Option B can be several years apart which can be challenging to represent in a forecast. New Administrative Guidance has been added with the link

Indication	Dialysis Patient (032)	Administer to hemodialysis patients and predialysis, peritoneal dialysis, and home dialysis patients	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Administer to persons who have severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Less severe antibody deficiencies (146)	Administer to persons who have less severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., selective IgA deficiency and IgG subclass deficiency).	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Administer to persons who have complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	Persistent complement, properdin, or factor B deficiency (151)	Administer to persons who have persistent complement component deficiencies, particularly C1, C2, C3, and C4 deficiencies.	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Administer to persons who have a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	Generalized malignant neoplasm (156)	Administer to persons who have generalized malignant neoplasm.	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	2 years	6 years	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	2 years	6 years	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, PCV13 and/or PPSV23 vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery or initiation of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	2 years	6 years	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, PCV13 and/or PPSV23 vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery or initiation of therapy.
Indication	Anatomical or functional asplenia (160)	Administer to persons with anatomic or functional asplenia, including sickle cell disease.	2 years	6 years	When elective splenectomy is being planned, PCV13 and/or PPSV23 vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery or initiation of therapy.

Administrative Guidance	Based on shared clinical decision-making, 1 dose of PCV20 may be administered at least 5 years after the last pneumococcal vaccine dose provided the patient previously received both PCV13 and PPSV23 with at least one dose of PPSV23 received on or after 65 years of age.

Series Name	Pneumococcal risk 19+ years CSF Leaks or Cochlear Implants PCV-PPSV series
Target Disease	Pneumococcal
Vaccine Group	Pneumococcal
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	Adults who have received PCV13 please consult the following for PCV20 or PPSV23 options: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/pneumo/downloads/pneumo-vaccine-timing.pdf
Administrative Guidance	When PCV15 is used, the recommended interval between administration of PCV15 and PPSV23 is on or after 1 year. A minimum interval of 8 weeks can be considered for adults with an immunocompromising condition, cochlear implant, or cerebrospinal fluid leak to minimize the risk for IPD caused by serotypes unique to PPSV23 in these vulnerable groups
Administrative Guidance	Based on shared clinical decision-making, 1 dose of PCV20 may be administered at least 5 years after the last pneumococcal vaccine dose provided the patient previously received both PCV13 and PPSV23 with at least one dose of PPSV23 received on or after 65 years of age.

Series Name	Pneumococcal risk 19+ years immunocompromised PCV-PPSV-PPSV series
Target Disease	Pneumococcal
Vaccine Group	Pneumococcal
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	Adults who have received PCV13 please consult the following for PCV20 or PPSV23 options: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/pneumo/downloads/pneumo-vaccine-timing.pdf
Administrative Guidance	When PCV15 is used, the recommended interval between administration of PCV15 and PPSV23 is on or after 1 year. A minimum interval of 8 weeks can be considered for adults with an immunocompromising condition, cochlear implant, or cerebrospinal fluid leak to minimize the risk for IPD caused by serotypes unique to PPSV23 in these vulnerable groups
Administrative Guidance	Based on shared clinical decision-making, 1 dose of PCV20 may be administered at least 5 years after the last pneumococcal vaccine dose provided the patient previously received both PCV13 and PPSV23 with at least one dose of PPSV23 received on or after 65 years of age.

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	19 years	n/a	n/a

Administrative Guidance	Adults who have received PCV13 please consult the following for PCV20 or PPSV23 options: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/pneumo/downloads/pneumo-vaccine-timing.pdf
Administrative Guidance	Based on shared clinical decision-making, 1 dose of PCV20 may be administered at least 5 years after the last pneumococcal vaccine dose provided the patient previously received both PCV13 and PPSV23 with at least one dose of PPSV23 received on or after 65 years of age.

Indication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Administer to persons who have partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	19 years	n/a	n/a

Indication	Transplantation (157)	Administer to persons who have received a transplant.	19 years	n/a	n/a
Indication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Administer to persons who are undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	19 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, PCV and/or PPSV23 vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery or initiation of therapy.
Indication	Radiation therapy (159)	Administer to persons who are undergoing radiation therapy.	19 years	n/a	When immunocompromising therapy is being planned, PCV and/or PPSV23 vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery or initiation of therapy.
Indication	Anatomical or functional asplenia (160)	Administer to persons with anatomic or functional asplenia, including sickle cell disease.	19 years	n/a	When elective splenectomy is being planned, PCV and/or PPSV23 vaccination should be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery or initiation of therapy.

Series Name	Pneumococcal 65+ 2-dose PCV-PPSV23 series
Target Disease	Pneumococcal
Vaccine Group	Pneumococcal
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	Adults who have received PCV13 please consult the following for PCV20 or PPSV23 options: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/pneumo/downloads/pneumo-vaccine-timing.pdf
Administrative Guidance	Based on shared clinical decision-making, 1 dose of PCV20 may be administered at least 5 years after the last pneumococcal vaccine dose provided the patient previously received both PCV13 and PPSV23 with at least one dose of PPSV23 received on or after 65 years of age.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Polio 4-dose series	Four dose schedule.  Dose 3 can be skipped if it is not administered by age 4 years resulting in a 3 dose series.

Polio 5-dose series	This series is for when four doses are given prior to 4 years (the 4th dose is not required for protection against polio). This series accommodates this without marking the extra dose invalid.

Polio Adult Catch-up series	This series supports validation of adult catch-up doses if an adult was never vaccinated against polio

Polio risk adult series	Risk-based which is used only for patients with frequent increased risk. Only one additional dose is required if a primary series has been completed.
changeHistory:
Version	4.45	Publication Date: 07/27/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	4-dose and 5-dose Series -> Updated Administrative Guidance	Persons who have not received a valid dose on or after 4 years of age should receive one final catch-up dose. For those vaccinated prior to 2010 this may result in a 5th dose.	Persons who received 4 doses of IPV before August 7, 2009 can be considered fully vaccinated for polio, regardless of age of the last dose, and it is not necessary to routinely administer an additional dose for these persons. If they are at increased risk of poliovirus exposure, they should be offered a single lifetime booster dose of IPV.	Updated language to better describe pre-August 7, 2009 vaccination.
Change	2	4-dose and 5-dose Series -> Doses 2+ -> Age -> Maximum Age	18 years	n/a	ACIP now recommends adults (aged 18+) who never received polio vaccination as a child to receive a polio. This also includes persons who begin vaccination under 18 years of age and then turn 18 during the midst of vaccination. 
Change	3	New Series	n/a	New Adult Catch-up Series	ACIP now recommends adults (aged 18+) who never received polio vaccination as a child to receive a polio. It is believed it will be extremely rare for an adult who was born and raised in the U.S. to be unvaccinated. This series will only forecast once the first dose is administered.
Change	4	Risk Adult -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	When there is not enough time to give three doses of IPV according to the recommended intervals, then an accelerated schedule of 3 doses at least 4 weeks apart can be used. If the accelerated schedule cannot be completed before the situation that puts someone at increased risk of exposure, the remaining doses should be given as soon as possible.	Language from: https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd/polio/hcp/recommendations.html
Change	5	Risk Adult -> Dose 3 -> Interval -> Absolute Minimum Interval	6 months - 4 days	4 weeks - 4 days	To support the possibility of an accelerated schedule having been administered. 

Version	4.41	Publication Date: 03/07/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	4-dose and 5-dose Series -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	Persons who have not received a valid dose on or after 4 years of age should receive one final catch-up dose. For those vaccinated prior to 2010 this may result in a 5th dose.	CDC is now recommending that persons receive a catch-up dose if they have not received a dose on or after 4 years of age. CDC specifically does not recommend a mass recall of all patients, just catch them up as they are encountered. As such, CDSi has not changed any logic to change these kids from complete to not complete which would impact coverage rates and recall activities. Rather, administrative guidance was added. If a 5th dose is administered it will be validated in the 5-dose series.

Version	4.39	Publication Date: 12/13/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All Series -> Updated administrative guidance	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV), only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV) on or after 4/1/2016, only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.	Made minor tweak to associate the tOPV review to those on or after 4/1/2016

Version	4.38	Publication Date: 10/28/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	5-dose series -> Dose 3 -> Removed Inadvertent Vaccine	CVX 02	removed	If administered, this should count as a valid dose. CVX 02 was listed in both allowable and inadvertent. Removing this from inadvertent, but leaving it in allowable will allow this dose to be considered valid.
Change	2	5-dose series -> Dose 5 -> New Allowable Vaccine 	n/a	Added CVX 02 (trivalent OPV)	tOPV - if administered - can count towards U.S. vaccination. This vaccine was missing for this dose and was incorrectly listed as an inadvertent vaccine. See next change for removal as an inadvertent vaccine
Change	3	5-dose series -> Dose 5 -> Removed Inadvertent Dose	CVX 02	removed	If administered, this should count as a valid dose. CVX 02 was listed in both allowable and inadvertent. Removing this from inadvertent, but leaving it in allowable will allow this dose to be considered valid.

Version	4.37	Publication Date: 10/18/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab -> Question about which OPV vaccine counts	CVX 02 (tOPV) is the only valid OPV vaccine in the mixed and all OPV series. Because tOPV is no longer in use, it has been removed as the Preferable Vaccine for the 4-dose OPV series (leaving no Preferable Vaccines).	CVX 02 (tOPV) is the only OPV vaccine to count towards U.S. vaccination. tOPV is rarely used after 4/1/2016, but does count if it has been administered. At this time, tOPV is listed as an allowable vaccine to support cases when tOPV is actually administered. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.	Clarified that tOPV is still used in special circumstances after April 2016 and - if used - it can count towards U.S. Vaccination.
Change	2	4-dose series -> Admin Guidance	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV), only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. As of April 2016, tOPV is no longer available or in use.	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV), only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.	Clarified that tOPV is still used in special circumstances after April 2016 and - if used - it can count towards U.S. Vaccination.
Change	3	5-dose series -> New Admin Guidance	n/a	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV), only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.	Clarified that tOPV is still used in special circumstances after April 2016 and - if used - it can count towards U.S. Vaccination.
Change	4	Risk Adult series -> New Admin Guidance	n/a	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV), only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.	Clarified that tOPV is still used in special circumstances after April 2016 and - if used - it can count towards U.S. Vaccination.
Change	5	Risk Adult series -> Dose 1, 2, & 3 -> New Allowable Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX 02 (trivalent OPV)	tOPV - if administered - can count towards U.S. vaccination. This vaccine was missing for the Risk Series as an allowable vaccine.

Version	4.32
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Adult -> All Doses -> Allowable Vaccine (CVX 195) -> Begin Age	6 yrs - 4 days	6 years - 4 days	Typo corrected to fully spell out the word years.

Version	4.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Preferred vaccines in 4 and 5 dose series	CVX 146 was not included as a preferred vaccine	Added CVX as a preferred vaccine where appropriate per MMWR in both the 4 and 5 dose series.	MMWR published on February 7, 2020: https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/pdfs/mm6905a5-H.pdf
Change	2	Contraindications	n/a	Added two new vaccine-specific Contraindications to support CVX 146 (Vaxelis)	Per package insert: https://www.fda.gov/media/119465/download

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New CVX	N/A	Added CVX 195	New Non-U.S. vaccine was added to the CVX code set. This CVX was added as an allowable vaccine as the booster vaccine in each series per the package label.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Dose 4 of the 4-dose series	Minimum Age of 4 years and Absolute Minimum Interval of 6 months - 4 days	Alternate values added	Alternate supporting data was added to support a historical recommendation from 2009.
Change	4	4-dose series	N/A	Added historical recommendations for dose 4	Requirements for the 4th dose were clarified in the August 7 2009 MMWR.

Version	3.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All 4-dose series	Three different series exists for all IPV, all OPV and Mixed	The series have been condensed into a single 4-dose series.	Given the availability of poliovirus vaccines and the requirements of the existing series, we were able to consolidate the series into a single 4-dose series.

Version	3.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Conditional Skip for Dose 3 of the 5-dose IPV series	n/a	A Conditional Skip requirement was added to Dose 3 to bring the 5-dose IPV series in line with the 4-dose IPV series.	This was missed previously and should have been added in version 3.2 when the series was created.
Change	2	Dose 4 Maximum Age of the 5-dose IPV Series	n/a	18 years	This should be 18 years to be consistent with all Standard Polio recommendations and is present in all doses across all standard series.
Change	3	Default Series Value on 5-dose IPV Series	Yes	No	This should not have been set to the Yes. The default series in Polio Standard series is the 4-dose IPV only series.

Version	3.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Conditional Skip for Dose 3 of the 4-dose mixed IPV-OPV series	n/a	A Conditional Skip requirement was added to Dose 3 to bring the mixed series in line with the 4-dose IPV series.	Updated to meet recent guidance (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6601a6.htm) that 3 doses of a mixed series are sufficient given the appropriate timing of the final dose.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Conditional Skip for Dose 3 of the 4-dose IPV series and the 4-dose OPV series	Both an age (4 years) and interval (6 months) needed to be satisfied as separate Conditional Skip conditions	Removed 6 month interval to skip the dose.	Updated to meet recent clarification on children receiving doses near the age of 4 years.  Previously, the patient must have been both 4 years AND 6 months removed from the previous dose before the dose could be skipped.  This change does NOT change the fact that the last dose must be 6 months from the previous dose once administered.
Change	2	Product Path on 5-dose series	Yes	No	The 5-dose series shouldn't be promoted as a product path series or given any select best series preference.  This series is reserved for situations after an "extra dose" is administered due to combination vaccines around the 18 month mark.
Change	3	Interval requirements on Dose 4 in the 5-dose series	no defined interval	Previous dose interval of 0 days	The change is merely documentation in nature to be explicit that this is a 0 day interval as opposed to having an undefined interval which may cause confusion.
Change	4	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.
Change	5	Inadvertent Dose on all series	N/A	All monovalent, bivalent or unspecified OPV vaccines	Per a clarification from CDC, all monovalent, bivalent and unspecified doses of OPV are considered inadvertent doses.
Change	6	Preferable Vaccine on 4-dose OPV series	CVX 02	N/A	As of April 2016, trivalent OPV has been replaced with bivalent OPV. Monovalent OPV (for all 3 serotypes) is available but used primarily in the case of outbreaks. Only trivalent OPV counts towards completion. Given that trivalent OPV is no longer available, there is no preferable vaccine for an all OPV series anymore.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk Adult Series Conditional Skip	N/A	1	Added Set ID to the Conditional Skip conditions for Doses 1 and 2.
Change	2	Series	No 5-dose IPV series	New 5-dose IPV series added	Added to accommodate the standard administration recommendations for IPV containing vaccines (http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_combo.asp#DTaPIPVHib).
Change	3	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Change	2	Absolute Minimum Interval and  Minimum Interval for Dose 4 of the All OPV 4 Dose Series	6 months	4 weeks	To clarify that a 6 month interval for Dose 4 only applies when Dose 3 is an IPV containing vaccine
Change	3	Earliest Recommended Interval and Latest Recommended Interval for All OPV 4 Dose Series	N/A	Intervals removed	The OPV series should never be forecast in the United States, therefore these intervals are no longer relevant

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for polio?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/polio.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about polio?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_pol.asp	n/a
FAQs	Why is previous diagnosis with polio not considered an immunity, negating the need for vaccination?	Immunity to one serotype of polio doesn't provider significant immunity to other serotypes. For full immunity, vaccination is still required.	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_pol.asp	The immunity tab does not contain any factors which indicate immunity.
FAQs	If a child is older than 4 years, can the all IPV series be reduced to 3 doses?	The recommendation is for 4 doses even after 4 years of age unless 6 months have passed since the second dose. At that point, the recommendation would be to reduce the number of doses to 3.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf	Dose 3 of the all IPV series has Conditional Skip logic that allows the dose to be skipped if BOTH a minimum age and minimum interval from dose 2 are achieved.
FAQs	If 4 doses of IPV at appropriate intervals are sufficient, why is there a 5 dose series documented in CDSi?	Because some combination vaccines are recommended to be administered at intervals different than the recommendations for IPV alone, it is possible to receive 4 valid doses of an IPV containing vaccine before the age of 4 years and still require a 5th dose after age 4.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5830a3.htm	The fourth dose in the 5-dose IPV series does not enforce any age or interval requirements. It is intended to validate a fourth dose of an IPV containing vaccine before the age of 4 years.
FAQs	Why does the adult risk series have 3 doses when at risk individuals are recommended to have a single additional dose?	An adult with a history of complete vaccination does require only a single additional dose, however, per ACIP recommendations adults without documentation of a complete series should receive 3 doses.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr4905a1.htm	Doses 1 and 2 of the adult risk series have Conditional Skip logic that allows the doses to be skipped if the patient has documented evidence of having completed the primary series already.
FAQs	Which OPV formulations count towards completion of the polio recommendations?	Only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations	https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6601a6.htm?s_cid=mm6601a6_e	CVX 02 (tOPV) is the only OPV vaccine to count towards U.S. vaccination. tOPV is rarely used after 4/1/2016, but does count if it has been administered. At this time, tOPV is listed as an allowable vaccine to support cases when tOPV is actually administered. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations. With regards to CVX 89 (Polio Unspecified formulation) and CVX 182 (OPV Unspecified). Both of these can count towards U.S. vaccination if given before 4/1/2016, but not after. At this time CDSi does not have effective and cessation dates for vaccines, but is planning to add this as part of the next major release (5.0).

series:
Series Name	Polio 4-dose series
Target Disease	Polio
Vaccine Group	Polio
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV) on or after 4/1/2016, only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.
Administrative Guidance	Persons who received 4 doses of IPV before August 7, 2009 can be considered fully vaccinated for polio, regardless of age of the last dose, and it is not necessary to routinely administer an additional dose for these persons. If they are at increased risk of poliovirus exposure, they should be offered a single lifetime booster dose of IPV.

Series Name	Polio adult catch-up series
Target Disease	Polio
Vaccine Group	Polio
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	Adults (aged > 18 years) who are known or suspected to be unvaccinated or incompletely vaccinated against polio should complete a primary vaccination series with IPV.
Administrative Guidance	In general, unless there are specific reasons to believe they were not vaccinated, most adults who were born and raised in the United States can assume they were vaccinated against polio as children. Polio vaccination has been part of the routine childhood immunization schedule for decades and is still part of the routine childhood immunization schedule. Adults who received any childhood vaccines almost certainly were vaccinated for polio.

Series Name	Polio risk adult series
Target Disease	Polio
Vaccine Group	Polio
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	When evaluating doses of oral polio vaccine (OPV) on or after 4/1/2016, only documentation specifying receipt of trivalent vaccine (tOPV) constitutes proof of vaccination according to the U.S. polio vaccination recommendations. Proper documentation of which OPV vaccine was received is critical to validation of records against U.S. vaccination recommendations.
Administrative Guidance	When there is not enough time to give three doses of IPV according to the recommended intervals, then an accelerated schedule of 3 doses at least 4 weeks apart can be used. If the accelerated schedule cannot be completed before the situation that puts someone at increased risk of exposure, the remaining doses should be given as soon as possible.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html
