Rabies risk continuous exposure series	Risk-based series which is used only for patients with continuous exposure risk. The booster series occurs at 6 month intervals.

Rabies risk frequent exposure series	Risk-based series which is used only for patients with frequent exposure risk. The booster series occurs at 2 year intervals.

Rabies risk infrequent exposure series	Risk-based series which is used only for patients with infrequent exposure risk. A single booster may be needed depending upon duration of exposure.
changeHistory:
Version	4.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk continuous exposure series -> Admin Guidance	The 6 month booster should only be given after a serum sample has been tested for rabies virus neutralizing antibody. The booster should be administered if the serum titer fails to maintain a value of at least complete neutralization of a 1:5 serum dilution by rapid fluorescent focus inhibition test.	The 6 month booster should only be given after a rabies antibody titer. The booster should be administered if the titer falls below 0.5 IU/mL.	Updated definition in 2022 ACIP MMWR
Change	2	Risk continuous exposure series -> Indications	Single Indication for Rabies Researchers	Two additional indications have been added for 1) rabies vaccines production facilities 2) rabies testing facilities	New risk categories in 2022 ACIP MMWR
Change	3	Risk continuous exposure series -> Dose 3 -> Skip Conditions	N/A	Created skip conditions to skip dose 3 starting on May 6, 2022.	Starting on May 6, 2022 (MMWR Publication Date) this series no longer requires three doses. 2 doses are sufficient. A skip condition was utilized to continue to validate 3-dose series which occurred prior to May 6, 2022.
Change	4	Risk frequent exposure series -> Admin Guidance	The 6 month booster should only be given after a serum sample has been tested for rabies virus neutralizing antibody. The booster should be administered if the serum titer fails to maintain a value of at least complete neutralization of a 1:5 serum dilution by rapid fluorescent focus inhibition test.	The 6 month booster should only be given after a rabies antibody titer. The booster should be administered if the titer falls below 0.5 IU/mL.	Updated definition in 2022 ACIP MMWR
Change	5	Risk frequent exposure series -> Indications	2008 frequent exposure risk factors	Removed 2008 frequent exposure risk factors and added 2022 frequent exposure risk factors	New risk categories in 2022 ACIP MMWR
Change	6	Risk frequent exposure series -> Dose 3 -> Skip Conditions	N/A	Created skip conditions to skip dose 3 starting on May 6, 2022.	Starting on May 6, 2022 (MMWR Publication Date) this series no longer requires three doses. 2 doses are sufficient. A skip condition was utilized to continue to validate 3-dose series which occurred prior to May 6, 2022.
Change	7	Risk infrequent exposure series	N/A	New Series	New series created per 2022 ACIP MWMR exposure categories.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Minimum Age To Start for all risk series	18 years	0 days	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Series Name	Risk infrequent exposure series
Target Disease	Rabies
Vaccine Group	Rabies
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	For persons who risk for rabies exposure is greater than 3 years, two options are available within the 3 years after primary series. 1) a one-time a titer check at 1-3 years after the primary series. A single booster should be administered if the titer is below 0.5 IU/mL. 2) preemptively receive a one-time booster on or after day 21 to year 3 after completion of the 2-dose primary series.
Administrative Guidance	For persons who risk for rabies exposure is greater than 3 years, but who have not had a titer or booster within three years can be realinged with ACIP recommendations through a one-time titer and booster if titer is below 0.5 IU/mL. Once boosted, titers should be checked no sooner than 1 week (preferable 2-4 weeks) later to ensure a titer of at least 0.5 UI/mL.
Administrative Guidance	For persons who risk for rabies exposure is less than 3 years (e.g., short-term volunteer providing hands-on animal care or infrequent traveler with no high-risk travel past 3 years), no boosting is recommended.

Indication	International travel with possible contact with animals in areas where rabies is enzootic and immediate access to appropriate medical care might be limited (144)	Administer to persons with plans for international travel with possible contact with animals in areas where rabies is enzootic and immediate access to appropriate medical care might be limited.	0 days	n/a	PrEP considerations include whether the travelers 1) will be performing occupational or recreational activities that increase risk for exposure to potentially rabid animals (particularly dogs) and 2) might have difficulty getting prompt access to safe PEP (e.g., rural part of a country or far from closest PEP clinic)

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Rotavirus 3-dose series	Recommended 3-dose Rotavirus series.  Administer the first dose at age 6 through 14 weeks (maximum age: 14 weeks 6 days).
Rotavirus 3-dose series	Vaccination should not be initiated for infants aged 15 weeks 0 days or older.  No doses should be administered after 8 months 0 days.

Rotavirus late start at 15 weeks 3-dose series	For infants to whom dose 1 of rotavirus vaccine is administered INADVERTENTLY at age 15 weeks and 0 days or older.
Rotavirus late start at 15 weeks 3-dose series	The rest of the rotavirus vaccination series should be completed by age 8 months and 0 days because timing of dose 1 should not affect the safety and efficacy of any subsequent dose(s).

Rotavirus 2-dose series	If Rotavirus, monovalent (Rotarix) vaccine is administered at ages 2 and 4 months, a dose at 6 months is not indicated.
Rotavirus 2-dose series	No doses should be administered after 8 months 0 days.

Rotavirus late start at 15 weeks 2-dose series	For infants to whom dose 1 of Rotavirus, monovalent (Rotarix) vaccine is administered INADVERTENTLY at age 15 weeks and 0 days or older.
Rotavirus late start at 15 weeks 2-dose series	The rest of the rotavirus vaccination series should be completed by age 8 months and 0 days because timing of dose 1 should not affect the safety and efficacy of any subsequent dose(s).

	2	General Update	N/A	Added Immunity Tab.  	To document evidence of immunity where applicable.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Absolute Minimum Age: Dose 1: Monovalent 2-dose Late Start Series	No Value	15 weeks	Consistent with 3-dose late start series, the absolute minimum age should be explicitly specified for clarity.
Change	4	Absolute Minimum Age and Minimum Age: Dose 3: 3-dose Late Start Series	14 Weeks - 4 days and 14 Weeks respectively	No Value for both.	Consistent with dose 2 in late start series, the (Absolute) minimum age isn't important as the child has already begun the series.  This was a copy/paste error from standard 3-dose series.
faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for rotavirus?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/rotavirus.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about rotavirus?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_rota.asp	n/a
FAQs	If the rotavirus vaccine is a live virus vaccine why is it not part of the Live Virus Conflict supporting data?	Per ACIP general recommendations the rotavirus vaccine can be administered simultaneously or at any interval before or after other live vaccines if indicated.	https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/timing.html	Rotavirus does not appear in the Live Virus Conflict supporting data and the normal live virus constraints should not be applied during evaluation and forecasting.

Series Name	Rotavirus late start at 15 weeks 3-dose series
Target Disease	Rotavirus
Vaccine Group	Rotavirus
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	For children with known or suspected altered immunocompetence, ACIP advises consultation with an immunologist or infectious diseases specialist before administration of rotavirus vaccine.  Children who are immunocompromised because of congenital immunodeficiency, or hematopoietic stem cell or solid organ transplantation sometimes experience severe, prolonged, and even fatal wild-type rotavirus gastroenteritis.
Administrative Guidance	Vaccination should not be initiated for infants age 15 weeks 0 days or older because there are insufficient data on the safety of dose #1 in older infants. Infants for whom the first dose of rotavirus vaccine was inadvertently administered at age 15 weeks or older should receive the remaining doses of the series at the routinely recommended intervals.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	Use of Respiratory Syncytial Virus Vaccines in Older Adults - https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/72/wr/mm7229a4.htm?s_cid=mm7229a4_w
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

1-dose series	Single dose series for those under 8 months of age

SERIES GROUP 2 | RISK

1-dose 60+ years SCDM series	Single dose series for those aged 60 years and older based on shared clinical decision making
changeHistory:
Version	4.53	Publication Date: 02/14/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose -> Removed Administrative Guidance	CDC has issued a Health Alert Network (HAN) Health Advisory to provide options for clinicians to protect infants from respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in the context of a limited supply of nirsevimab. https://emergency.cdc.gov/han/2023/han00499.asp	Removed	Nirsevimab supply is now adequate per the following COCA announcement. https://emergency.cdc.gov/newsletters/coca/2024/010524a.html
Change	2	Risk under 20 months -> Removed Administrative Guidance	CDC has issued a Health Alert Network (HAN) Health Advisory to provide options for clinicians to protect infants from respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in the context of a limited supply of nirsevimab. https://emergency.cdc.gov/han/2023/han00499.asp	Removed	Nirsevimab supply is now adequate per the following COCA announcement. https://emergency.cdc.gov/newsletters/coca/2024/010524a.html
Change	3	Risk Pregnant 1-dose -> New Administrative Guidance	CDC has issued a Health Alert Network (HAN) Health Advisory to provide options for clinicians to protect infants from respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in the context of a limited supply of nirsevimab. https://emergency.cdc.gov/han/2023/han00499.asp	Removed	Nirsevimab supply is now adequate per the following COCA announcement. https://emergency.cdc.gov/newsletters/coca/2024/010524a.html
Change	4	1-dose 60+ years SCDM -> Dose 1 -> Age -> Absolute Minimum Age	0 days	50 years	This was moved from down to 0 days last release to support update Clinical SME guidance to not repeat early administrations. This creates an overlap with the birth through 20 months nirsevimab set of series as well as the risk-based pregnancy series. In an effort to support early administration of 60+ SCDM doses, but not to overlap with other cohorts this value has been updated to 50 years of age.

Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose -> Administrative Guidance	Except in rare circumstances, nirsevimab is not needed for most infants younger than age 8 months who are born 14 or more days after their mother received RSV vaccine.	Except in rare circumstances, nirsevimab is not needed for most infants younger than age 8 months who are born 14 or more days after their mother received Pfizer/Abrysvo RSV vaccine.	Fine-tuned to specifically note it is the Pfizer/Abrysvo RSV vaccine.
Change	2	1-dose -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	The infant should receive nirsevimab younger than 8 months if the pregnant person received an RSV vaccine, but encountered any one of the following issues. The dose was administered in the incorrect route/site, was of lower than recommended volume, was administered before 24 weeks gestation, was not the Pfizer/Abrysvo product, had preparation errors prior to administration, or had storage issues.	Added based on RSV clinical SME guidance

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	1-dose -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	Nirsevimab is not needed for most infants born 14 days or more after maternal RSVpreF vaccination	ACIP now recommends either maternal vaccination with RSVpreF (Abrysvo) or infant vaccination with nirsevimab (Beyfortus). If the maternal vaccination occurs at least 14 days prior to birth, the infant does not need nirsevimab.
Change	2	1-dose -> Dose 1 -> New Allowable Vaccine	304, 306, 307	Added new CVX 315	CVX 315 (MAB Unspecified) was created and can count as valid for this series and dose

Nirsevimab is not needed for most infants born 14 days or more after maternal RSVpreF vaccination	ACIP now recommends either maternal vaccination with RSVpreF (Abrysvo) or infant vaccination with nirsevimab (Beyfortus). Change	13	Risk under 20 months -> Dose 3 -> New Skip Conditions	n/a	Added a new set of skip conditions specific to Evaluation Context and Forecast Context	These new skip conditions address the gap described in the previous change entry. Change	14	New Series	n/a	New series for Maternal RSV recommendations Risk Pregnant 1-dose	ACIP now recommends either maternal vaccination with RSVpreF (Abrysvo) or infant vaccination with nirsevimab (Beyfortus). If the maternal vaccination occurs at least 14 days prior to birth, the infant does not need nirsevimab.
Change	15	1-dose 60+ years SCDM -> Dose 1 -> New Allowable Vaccine	303, 304, 305	Added new CVX 314	CVX 314 (Vaccine Unspecified) was created and can count as valid for this series and dose
Change	16	1-dose 60+ years SCDM -> Dose 1 -> New Inadvertent Vaccine	n/a	Added CVX codes 306, 307, 315	Any monoclonal antibody administered to this population would be an inadvertent administration and need to be repeated.

Version	4.47	Publication Date: 09/18/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk under 20 months -> Dose 1 -> Maximum Age	n/a	20 months	No doses of RSV are recommended for any person on/after 20 months
Change	2	Risk under 20 months -> Dose 2 -> Conditional Skip -> Start Date	45200	45108	The official seasonal dates per ACIP are 10/1 through 03/31, but doses that are administered shortly before or after the season can occur and should be counted as part of the season.
Change	3	Risk under 20 months -> Dose 2 -> Conditional Skip -> End Date	45382	45473	The official seasonal dates per ACIP are 10/1 through 03/31, but doses that are administered shortly before or after the season can occur and should be counted as part of the season.

Change	1	Contraindications -> Antigen Contraindication	Severe allergic reaction after previous dose of RSV vaccine (245)	Severe allergic reaction after previous dose of RSV vaccine (244)	The contraindication code had a typo. Rather than 245, it should be 244.
Change	2	2 new series	n/a	New series created * 1-dose * Risk 2-dose	Created in support of new ACIP recommendation for nirsevimab
Change	3	1-dose SCDM series rename	1-dose SCDM	1-dose 60+ years SCDM	With new recommendations for pediatric being a bit more descriptive is helpful
Change	4	1-dose 60+ years SCDM -> Select Patient Series -> Series Group Name	Standard	Standard 60+	Renaming this to make room for pediatric series group which will be the standard series group name.
Change	5	1-dose 60+ years SCDM -> Select Patient Series -> Series Group	1	3	Moving this down to make room for new series groups for younger patients. This is now similar to the Pneumococcal structure (age-based for peds, risk based, age-based for adult)

FAQs	ACIP noted that RSV sesason may differ locally. How will CDSi address this?	CDSi will publish Seasonal Recommendation Start and End Dates per ACIP. If local epidemiology dictates a different start and end date, local updates to CDSi supporting data would be necessary.	https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/rsv.html	The updates in CDSi should be relatively straightforward. Seasonal Dates are found within each dose (Seasonal Recommendation Start and End Dates). Further, Administrative Guidance and skip conditions should be reviewed for local seasonal dates which may need to be adjusted.

Administrative Guidance	Except in rare circumstances, nirsevimab is not needed for most infants younger than age 8 months who are born 14 or more days after their mother received Pfizer/Abrysvo RSV vaccine.
Administrative Guidance	The infant should receive nirsevimab younger than 8 months if the pregnant person received an RSV vaccine, but encountered any one of the following issues. antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

changeHistory:
Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Removed Contraindication	Immunocompromised (003)	Removed	This was removed as it is too broad and includes all forms of immunocompromise (mild-to-severe).
Change	2	Contraindications -> New Contraindication	n/a	Added Severe Immunocompromise (246)	This was added as a better classification which results in a contraindication.
Change	3	Risk 2-dose -> New Indication	n/a	Added new Indication "Household and close contacts of immunocompromised persons" (Code 073)	This was present in Measles, but missing in Mumps and Rubella

Version	4.39	Publication Date: 12/13/2022
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New PRIORIX vaccine	n/a	n/a	PRIORIX is the same CVX code as M-M-R II (03) with the same contraindications and is interchangeable in use. No changes were made to any Immunity, Contraindications, or Series tabs. Priorix was added to the overview tab.

Version	4.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 003 (Immunocompromised) was added as a contraindication	This is an existing PHINVADS code exchanged in HL7 (VXC27) and results in a contraindication.

Version	4.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Risk 2-dose Interval on Dose 2 Recommended Intervals	3 years and 6 years	4 weeks and n/a	This was incorrectly carried forward from the standard series. Patients at increased risk are recommended to receive their next dose 28 days apart.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
	3	New Risk 2-dose Series	N/A	Added 2-dose series for adults	This 2-dose series has been in Measles and Mumps since 3.0, but wasn't in rubella. Given the only active product in the U.S. is MMR, this helped align the three antigens.
	4	New Risk 2-dose ART Series	N/A	Created a new Series for patients who undergo antiviral therapy (ART)	Previously ART was included in the Risk 2-dose series, but wasn't forecasting properly in cases where a patient had received MMR prior to ART.
Change	5	Minimum Age To Start for Risk 1-dose and Risk 2-dose series	N/A	6 months and 18 months	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 012 (Family history of altered immunocompetence) added as contraindication.	Updates made to the ACIP Best Practice Guidelines for Immunization.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 2 of the 2-dose series	N/A	Condition Skip logic added	A second dose of rubella vaccine is not required for adults. This brings the rubella supporting data in line with that for measles and mumps.
Change	2	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Version	3

	2	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Contraindication tab.  	To document contraindications where applicable
Change	3	Immunity	SNOMED codes were defined for each concept.	Immunity concepts now point to coded observations (which are mapped to SNOMED in schedule supporting data)	Coded observations are used consistently in the antigen supporting data.
Change	4	General Update	N/A	Added Inadvertent Vaccine	Some vaccines, when administered, should be immediately corrected.

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for rubella?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/mmr.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about rubella?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_mmr.asp	n/a
FAQs	Why is the standard rubella series documented as a 2-dose series when the ACIP recommendation is for only a single dose?	Because rubella is only available in the United States as part of the MMR vaccine, we have chosen to document it as a 2-dose series to be consistent with the supporting data for measles and mumps. This will prevent the necessary second dose of MMR as be labeled as "extraneous" when evaluating the rubella antigen.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6204a1.htm	The standard series is a 2-dose series.
FAQs	Why is there a travel based risk series when the ACIP recommendation only calls out measles for infants aged 6-11 months?	Because rubella is only available in the United States as part of the MMR vaccine, we have chosen to document it as a 2-dose series to be consistent with the supporting data for measles. This will prevent the necessary  dose of MMR prior to 12 months as be labeled as "invalid" when evaluating the rubella antigen.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6204a1.htm	A 1-dose risk base series has been created for rubella.
FAQs	Why does the dose for the risk series for travelers under the age of 12 months not count towards the standard series?	Children who received MMR vaccine before age 12 months should be considered potentially susceptible to rubella and should be revaccinated with 2 doses of MMR vaccine.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6204a1.htm	The risk series and standard series are in different series groups. Even if the risk series is completed, the full 2-dose standard series is required.
FAQs	Isn't rubella just for children?	No, adults born in 1957 or later should receive 1 dose unless they have acceptable evidence of immunity.	http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr6204a1.htm	The standard 2-dose series doesn't have any maximum age.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.

Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Standard series	This series starts with the standard 5 dose series for children < 7 years old.  It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered after 4 years.
Tetanus standard series	Doses 6, 7, and 8 address adolescent doses of Tdap/Td based on the number of valid doses received < 7 years.
Tetanus standard series	Dose 9 is the adolescent dose if no catch-up dosing is not needed.
Tetanus standard series	Dose 10 is the recurring dose.

Start at 12 months Series	This series has the same structure as the standard series, but is for patients who receive their first dose on or after 12 months of age. 
	Doses 1-5 are the standard 5 dose series for children < 7 years old.  It includes the ability to skip the 5th dose if the 4th dose is administered after 4 years.
Diphtheria standard series	Doses 6, 7, and 8 address adolescent doses of Tdap/Td based on the number of valid doses received < 7 years. 
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 9 is the adolescent (11-12 year) dose.
Diphtheria standard series	Dose 10 is the recurring dose

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Preferred vaccines in standard and Start at 12 month series	CVX 146 was not included as a preferred vaccine	Added CVX as a preferred vaccine where appropriate per MMWR.	MMWR published on February 7, 2020: https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/69/wr/pdfs/mm6905a5-H.pdf

Version	4.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Series Revamp	One Standard Series	2 series based on starting age	Revamp better aligns with Tdap catch-up Job Aid which is separated based on when the first dose was administered (before/after 12 months of age).
Change	2	Allowable Vaccine Maximum Age across all doses	All DT(P) containing entries had a maximum age of 19 years	Changed all entries to N/A	Per an Ask the Experts FAQ, while this is not preferred, these can be counted as a Td or Tdap vaccination if inadvertently administered regardless of age.
Change	3	Allowable Vaccines on the Repeating Booster	No DT(P) containing vaccines were in the list	Added all DT(P) containing vaccines	Per an Ask the Experts FAQ, while this is not preferred, these can be counted as a Td or Tdap vaccination if inadvertently administered regardless of age.

Version	4.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Overview tab updates to CVX 09	One entry for CVX 09	updated to create three rows for CVX 09	Updates to align with CDC Product Name mapped to CVX/MVX table which contain three records for various products. At this time, only one is active (TDVAX). This update has no impact on Series or Dose specific settings. The changes were contained to the overview tab.

Version	4.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	New CVX	N/A	Added CVX 195	New Non-U.S. vaccine was added to the CVX code set. This CVX was added as an allowable vaccine for those 6 years and over per the package label.
Change	2	New CVX	N/A	Added CVX 196	A new unspecified CVX code was published and subsequently added to CDSi.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Tdap Catch-up (Doses 6, 7, 8)	N/A	Several changes in the Conditional Skip and interval override settings	Tdap Catch-up doses (6, 7, 8) have been updated to reflect the newly released Tdap Catch-up Job Aid (https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/job-aids/tdap.pdf).
Change	4	Adolescent Tdap Dose at 11-12 years	Able to skip if Tdap was administered anytime after 7 years	Dose at 11-12 years is now recommended even if a Tdap was administered between the ages of 7 and 10 years old. Changes were to absolute minimum age and conditional skip.	Updated language in the 2019 yearly harmonized schedule and Tdap catch-up job aid.
Change	5	Conditional Skip Doses 1 through 5	Conditional Skip requirements applied to evaluation and forecast	Separate Conditional Skip requirements for evaluation and forecast	The "6 by 7" only applies to forecasting.

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Latest Recommended Age for Dose 9	13 years	13 years + 4 weeks	Updated to apply the standard 4 week extension for the Latest Recommended Age.

Version	3.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Absolute Minimum Interval for Dose 10	2 years	0 days	Updated to indicate that recurring doses of tetanus  are valid regardless of interval during the retrospective evaluation process.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 4 Minimum Age	12 Months	15 Months	Moved from 12 months to 15 months per 2017 harmonized schedule and 2017 General Best Practice Guidelines.
Change	2	Dose 4 Allowable Interval	4 Months	4 Months - 4 days	Clarification from CEB - and subsequent update to 2017 General Best Practice Guidelines - now allows for the grace period to be used here.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Version	3.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	CVX description update	DTaP-Hib-HepB (102)	DTP-Hib-HepB (102)	CVX 102 contains DTP, not DTaP.  Typo was corrected throughout spreadsheet.

Version	3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Contraindication tab.  	To document contraindications where applicable
Change	2	Preferable Vaccines	Forecast Vaccine Type  CVX (115) is 'Y' across all doses beginning at dose 6 on the Standard Series tab	Changed Forecast Vaccine Type CVX (115) from 'Y' to 'N'	Typo in version 2.3
	3	Antigen Series Overview tab - Vaccines	N/A 	Added CVX Codes (112) and (142) with a Status of "Inactive"	Unintentional omission in version 2.3
Change	4	General Update	N/A	Added Inadvertent Vaccine	Some vaccines, when administered, should be immediately corrected.
Change	5	General Update	From Most Recent (CVX)	From Most Recent (CVX List)	Updated to allow multiple CVX codes to be documented as part of the From Most Recent interval type

Version	2.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Doses 4 - 10 Allowable	N/A	Added CVX (35) - Tetanus Toxoid	This CVX code has been discontinued by the manufacturer; however it can still be used to record  historical records.  Note: This CVX Code has been missing since version 1.0. 

Version	2.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Conditional Skip	currentAge, noLimit, TBD	removed references and changed to "n/a"	Clean up of concepts not part of the final Conditional Skip data model.
Change	2	Standard Series Doses 1 through 5	6	5	Corrected Dose Count for Conditional Skip of description  "Dose is not required if the patient has received 6 or more total doses to date"

Version	2.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All doses - Interval	N/A	Added Interval Priority Skip	To determine, if applicable, when an interval override should be used.
Change	2	General Update	Removed Skip dose, Conditional Need, and Substitute Dose concepts	Added Conditional Skip concept	To better align with current ACIP recommendations. 
Change	3	Overview Tab - Vaccines	N/A	 Added (CVX 130) - Quadracel	Inadvertently omitted from previous version.

Version	2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Added 2015 Childhood and Adult Immunization Schedules  to the Resources area.	To provide current ACIP Immunization recommendations for Persons Aged 0 through 18 and Adults aged 19 years and older.
	2	General Update	N/A	Added Immunity Tab.  	To document evidence of immunity where applicable.

Version	1.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 6, 7, and 8 Skip Dose Trigger Age	11 years	removed 11 years and set to "n/a"	Doses 6, 7, 8 are the catch-up doses for Tdap/Td when DTaP was not fully administered.  These doses are still recommended for completion past 11 years so they should not have been skipped.  Removing the skip dose trigger age allows these recommendations to be met.
Change	2	Doses 1 - 5 Skip Dose Trigger Doses Administered	N/A	Added support for 6 doses by 7 years in DTaP	A 1991 MMWR statement for DTP recommends a maximum of 6 doses prior to 7 years of age regardless of validity.

Version	1.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Dose 4 Allowable Interval	not populated.  New logical component in version 1.7	4 months	4 months, which is acknowledged as an allowable interval was previously specified in the "Absolute Minimum Interval" on the interval logical component.  This worked in all cases except when spacing from a not valid interval.  The new allowable interval fixes this and allows the 4 month interval even from an invalid dose.

Version	1.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on all doses	All DTaP containing  vaccines had a vaccine type end age of 11 years	Changed to 19 years for all DTaP containing vaccines	Per 2014 Childhood/Adolescent Harmonized schedule - DTaP can be inadvertently administered through 18 years (less than 19 years) and be counted as the adolescent Tdap booster dose.

Version	1.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Allowable Vaccine on last dose	Only Td and Tdap based vaccines were listed as allowable vaccines	Carried all allowable vaccines from the previous dose down to the last dose.	Since the last dose could actually be administered at 7 years old, an allowable administration of DTaP and other allowable vaccines in the previous dose could still be administered and be considered valid.
Change	2	Skip Dose on Dose 9 in Series	N/A	Added a Trigger Target Dose value of 8 to properly skip the adolescent dose (dose 9) if dose 8 was satisfied	Td can be either recommended starting at 7 or 11 years depending upon DTaP administrations.  Previously, the supporting data would recommend a dose at 7 AND at 11 in certain situations.  This allows for skipping the 11 year recommendation if the child is recommended and receives dose(s) between 7 through 10 years.  Either dose 8 or 9 must be satisfied, but not both.
Change	3	Interval on Dose 9	Interval was specified	Removed Interval on 11 year Adolescent dose	A child who is "fully vaccinated" for DTaP by age 7 years is to be recommended for Tdap at age 11 years without regard to interval.  Similarly, the adolescent dose of Tdap can be administered without regard to interval from the last DTaP dose.  This is not the case, however, when the child enters age 7 years and is not fully vaccinated for DTaP and this is addressed in dose 6, 7, and 8 (catch-up doses) in the series.
Change	4	Dose 10	Not Specified in previous version.	Dose 10 added	Previously Dose 9 was the adolescent dose as well as the recurring 10 year booster dose.  These two requirements were separated into two different doses. Dose 9 is now the adolescent dose and Dose 10 is the recurring 10 year booster.

Version	1.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Latest Recommended Interval on Dose 9	N/A	10 years + 4 weeks	Based on clarification from NIPInfo.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous Values	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Substitute Dose	Missing conditions	Added substitutions to dose 6 for a child who is up-to-date to properly substitute the catch-up doses	A child who is up-to-date at age 7, doesn't need to go through the catch-up doses (6, 7, and 8).  This was missing in version 1.0 and forcing the child through the catch-up doses.
Change	4	Catch-up Doses 6 - 8 Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals	Values not specified	Added Latest Recommended Age and Latest Recommended Intervals to match the Earliest Recommended Age and Earliest Recommended Intervals for each dose.	These were empty before which resulted in a forecast with no Past Due Date.  Since the child is in catch-up at this point, the Past Due Date should align with the Recommended Date.
Change	5	Age Values on Dose 9	Values not specified	Absolute Minimum Age: 7 years Minimum Age: 11 Years Earliest Recommended Age: 11 Years Latest Recommended Age: 13 Years	There were no age values on the recurring dose which resulted in the 11 year dose for a child who was up-to-date with childhood DTaP as incorrect.
faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for tetanus?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/dtap.html  http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/tdap-td.html	n/a
FAQs	Where can I find answers to my questions about tetanus?	The Immunization Action Coalition hosts a web site answering common questions about immunizations	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_tet.asp	n/a
FAQs	Is there a maximum number of doses of DTaP a child should receive?	ACIP recommends that children receive no more than 6 doses of diphtheria and tetanus toxoids (e.g., DT, DTaP, DTP) before the seventh birthday because of concern about adverse reactions, primarily local reactions	http://www.immunize.org/askexperts/experts_tet.asp	Each of the first 5 doses in the standard series has Conditional Skip logic indicating that receiving 6 or more doses before the age of the 7 is sufficient grounds for skipping the dose.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Version	4.29
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Vaccine Contraindications	N/A	Added HIV/AIDS (code 154) to vaccine specific contraindications for Ty21a (Oral Typhoid)	General Best Practices added this to their list of contraindications in an errata update on April 26, 2022

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Minimum Age To Start for both Risk series	N/A	2 years	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

faq:
FAQs	Question	Answer	Reference	CDSi Manifestation
FAQs	Where can I find the most recent ACIP recommendations for typhoid?	The CDC publishes the most recent ACIP vaccine recommendations.	http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/vacc-specific/typhoid.html	n/a
FAQs	Why does the 4-dose series only have 2 doses?	Research by the CDSi project team indicated that most systems would likely only document one immunization event even though the individual is expected to take all 4 doses without physician oversight.	n/a	The first dose of the risk 4-dose series encompasses all 4 doses. The second dose in the series is the recurring dose required if the individual is at continued risk.
FAQs	If the oral Ty21a vaccine is a live virus vaccine why is it not part of the Live Virus Conflict supporting data?	Per ACIP general recommendations the typhoid vaccine can be administered simultaneously or at any interval before or after other live vaccines if indicated.	https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/timing.html	Typhoid does not appear in the Live Virus Conflict supporting data and the normal live virus constraints should not be applied during evaluation and forecasting.

Vaccine Contraindication	Contraindication (Code)	Text Description	Administrative Guidance	Vaccine Type (CVX)	Contraindication Begin Age	Contraindication End Age (less than)
Vaccine Contraindication	Antimicrobial or antimalarial taken within 72 hours (035)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has taken antimicrobial or antimalarial medications  within the previous 72 hours.	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	B-lymphocyte [humoral] - Severe antibody deficiencies (145)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has severe B-lymphocyte (humoral) - antibody deficiencies (e.g., X-linked agammaglobulinemia and common variable immunodeficiency).	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Complete defects (147)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has complete cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., severe combined immunodeficiency [SCID] disease, complete DiGeorge syndrome).	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - Partial defects (148)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has partial cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects (e.g., most patients with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, ataxia- telangiectasia).	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - interferon-gamma/Interleukin 12 axis deficiencies (149)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - interferon-gamma/Interleukin 12 axis deficiencies.	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	T-lymphocyte [cell-mediated and humoral] - interferon-gamma or interferon-alpha (150)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has cell-mediated or humoral T-lymphocyte defects related to interferon-gamma or interferon-alpha	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	Phagocytic function - Chronic granulomatous disease (152)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has phagocytic function - chronic granulomatous disease.	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	Phagocytic function - Leukocyte adhesion defect, and myeloperoxidase deficiency (153)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has a phagocytic function defect (e.g. leukocyte adhesion defect and myeloperoxidase deficiency).	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	HIV/AIDS - severely immunocompromised (154)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has HIV/AIDS and is severely immunocompromised (See the CDC general recommendations for a definition of "severely immunocompromised").	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	Generalized malignant neoplasm (156)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient has generalized malignant neoplasm.	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	Transplantation (157)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient received a transplant.	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	Immunosuppressive therapy (158)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient is undergoing immunosuppressive therapy. Immunosuppressive medications include those given to prevent solid organ transplant rejection, human immune mediators like interleukins and colony-stimulating factors, immune modulators like levamisol and BCG bladder-tumor therapy, and medicines like tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitors and anti-B cell antibodies. 	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a
Vaccine Contraindication	Radiation therapy (159)	Do not vaccinate with live attenuated typhoid virus (Ty21a) if the patient is undergoing radiation therapy.	n/a	Typhoid oral, live, attenuated (25)	n/a	n/a

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

Varicella 13+ 2-dose series	2 doses, 4 weeks apart for adolescents and adults receiving their 1st dose at age 13 years and older.
changeHistory:
Version	4.52	Publication Date: 01/02/2024
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications -> Removed Contraindication	Immunocompromised (003)	Removed	This was removed as it is too broad and includes all forms of immunocompromise (mild-to-severe).
Change	2	Contraindications -> New Contraindication	n/a	Added Severe Immunocompromise (246)	This was added as a better classification which results in a contraindication.
Change	3	Childhood 2-dose -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	HIV-infected people eligible for vaccination should get 2 doses of single-antigen varicella vaccine separated by 3 months. HIV-infected people should not get the combination MMRV vaccine.	This was added as a better classification which results in a contraindication.
Change	4	13+ 2-dose -> New Administrative Guidance	n/a	HIV-infected people eligible for vaccination should get 2 doses of single-antigen varicella vaccine separated by 3 months. HIV-infected people should not get the combination MMRV vaccine.	This was added as a better classification which results in a contraindication.

Version	4.41	Publication Date: 03/07/2023
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	13+ 2-dose series -> Select Patient Series -> Maximum Age to Start	50 years	n/a	Removed this to accommodate persons who are 50 years or older, but have no evidence of immunity to varicella. This removal then allows this series to be properly selected as the best series to forecast dose 2 in 4 weeks.

Version	4.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 003 (Immunocompromised) was added as a contraindication	This is an existing PHINVADS code exchanged in HL7 (VXC27) and results in a contraindication.

Version	4.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 168 (Chemotherapy) added as a contraindication	This has been a contraindication for quite some time in published recommendations, but was missing in CDSi.

Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Childhood 2-dose Series -> Default series	No	Yes	Neither standard series was defined as the default series which is used in cases where no doses have been administered to provide a generic forecast.

Version	3.8
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Upper ages on Varicella-containing vaccines	60 years	N/A	Updates to align with removal of 60 year upper age range in version 3.7.
Change	2	13+ Maximum Age to start	N/A	50 years	Updates to avoid overlapping recommendations for both varicella and zoster after the age of 50 years.

Version	3.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	13+ End Ages and Maximum Age to start	60 years	N/A	Updates made to end ages of Varicella based on new Zoster vaccine (Shingrix) and Ask the Expert clarifications.

Version	3.6
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindications	N/A	Code 012 (Family history of altered immunocompetence) added as contraindication.	Updates made to the ACIP Best Practice Guidelines for Immunization.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Absolute Minimum Age for Dose 2 of the Standard Childhood 2-dose series	12 months + 4 weeks	13 months	2017 General Best Practice Guidelines (Table 3-1, footnote (x)) indicates a 13 month absolute minimum age for Varicella-2.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.
Change	2	Childhood Series Maximum Age	N/A	60 years	Aligns with clarification that varicella containing vaccines are not valid after the age of 60 years.
Change	3	13+ Series Maximum Age and Maximum Age to Start	N/A	60 years	Aligns with clarification that varicella containing vaccines are not valid after the age of 60 years.

Version	3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added risk indication series	To provide support for underlying conditions which are indications for vaccination beyond the standard schedule
	2	Underlying Conditions	N/A	Added Contraindication tab.  	To document contraindications where applicable
Change	3	Immunity	SNOMED codes were defined for each concept.	Immunity concepts now point to coded observations (which are mapped to SNOMED in schedule supporting data)	Coded observations are used consistently in the antigen supporting data.
Change	4	General Update	N/A	Added Inadvertent Vaccine	Some vaccines, when administered, should be immediately corrected.
Change	5	General Update	From Most Recent (CVX)	From Most Recent (CVX List)	Updated to allow multiple CVX codes to be documented as part of the From Most Recent interval type

Version	2.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	All doses - Interval	N/A	Added Interval Priority Skip	To determine, if applicable, when an interval override should be used.
Change	2	General Update	Removed Skip dose, Conditional Need, and Substitute Dose concepts	Added Conditional Skip concept	To better align with current ACIP recommendations. 

Version	2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
	1	General Update	N/A	Added 2015 Childhood and Adult Immunization Schedules  to the Resources area.	To provide current ACIP Immunization recommendations for Persons Aged 0 through 18 and Adults aged 19 years and older.
	2	General Update	N/A	Added  Immunity Tab 	To document evidence of immunity where applicable.
Change	3	Allowable Vaccine End Age for Zoster across all doses and all series	N/A	50 Years	Since the minimum age for administering Zoster is 50, the Allowable Vaccine -Vaccine Type End age needed to be updated across all series. 

Version	1.7
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Childhood series: Dose 2: Allowable Interval	Not populated; New Logical Component	4 weeks	Moved the "Absolute Minimum Interval" of 4 weeks from "interval" to "allowable interval" to align with the purpose of the allowable interval and remove the conflict which existed with the grace period logic.

Version	1.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Childhood Series: Dose 1: Max Age	13 years	removed	The maximum age a patient is recommended to receive varicella is not 13 years old.  This is the age at which the child should follow a more condensed series.  13 years removed here, and added back in below to better control series selection.
Change	2	Childhood Series: Select Best Series: Max Age To Start	N/A	13 years	This now properly controls the series the patient should be on based on the age of the patient when the first dose was administered.

Version	1.1
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Updates	N/A	Added "Overview" section to Overview tab.  Cleaned up vaccine names in overview table and "series" tabs.	Inconsistencies between Vaccine table in overview tab and "series" tabs
Change	2	Preferable and Allowable Vaccines	N/A	Improved delineation between preferable and allowable vaccines through clear age range definition	Consistency effort across all antigens to clearly define preferred vaccines which should be given and allowable vaccines which can be given.
Change	3	Absolute Minimum Interval on Dose 2 of Adolescent Series	4 weeks	4 weeks - 4 days	Grace period should be allowed here.  Typo Correction.
Change	4	Latest Recommended Age on Dose 1 of Adolescent Series	No Value	13 Years	Previous version didn't have a latest recommended age which means a forecast without a "Past Due Date".  Since the child is lapse, it's important to create a past due date as these drive recall efforts.
Change	5	Latest Recommended Interval on Dose 2 of Adolescent Series	9 weeks	4 weeks	At this point, the child is already severely overdue for standard childhood varicella dose 2.  The interval according to the catch-up schedule is 4 weeks.

antigenSeriesOverview:
Overview	Each Supporting Data file is targeted to one specific antigen and is comprised of three or more tabs.
Overview
Overview	The Antigen Series Overview tab is merely a high-level tab to orient the user in regards to the other tabs.  It should not be used to infer, interpret, or assume any logic or values.
Overview
Overview	The Change History tab is used to document the changes to the supporting data.

Overview	The FAQ tab is used to document frequently asked questions about the content of the supporting data.
Overview
Overview	The Immunity tab is used to document evidence of immunity. Immunity Guideline and Exclusion Condition values can be found in the Coded Observation Schedule Supporting data file.
Overview
Overview	The Contraindications tab is used to document underlying patient conditions which may contraindicate the administration of a dose or the use of a particular vaccine.
Overview
Overview	Each subsequent tab contains structured detail for an Antigen Series, or "path to immunity", and should be used for CDS purposes
Overview	Series may either be a standard age based series or risk based series based on underlying patient conditions.
Overview	The number of Antigen Series tabs varies based on the antigen and associated ACIP recommendation complexities.


Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Persons Aged 0 through 18 years - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/child/0-18yrs-child-combined-schedule.pdf
Resources	Recommended Immunization Schedule for Adults aged 19 and over - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/schedules/downloads/adult/adult-combined-schedule.pdf 
Resources	Best Practices Guidance of the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) - https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/hcp/acip-recs/general-recs/index.html
Resources	IIS Standard Code Sets - http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/programs/iis/code-sets.html

changeHistory:
Version	4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	General Update	N/A	Effective Date and Cessation Date added to certain Logical Components	Version 4.0 includes support for historical recommendations which requires the selection of relevant supporting data depending on the date of the dose being evaluating or the date the forecast is being made.
Change	2	General Update	N/A	Skip Context added to Conditional Skip	The Conditional Skip requirements for a given dose may vary based on whether an evaluation or forecast is being made.
Change	3	Minimum Age To Start for Risk 1-dose series	N/A	9 months	Minimum Age To Start updated to match the earliest Indication Begin Age

Version	3.5
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Vaccine Contraindication	n/a	Contraindication for Breastfeeding added for Stamaril (CVX 183)	New recommendations indicate a contraindication for breastfeeding mothers unless breastfeeding is suspended for 14 days after administration.

Version	3.4
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Indications in Risk 1-dose Series	60 years	n/a	60 years+ is a Precaution to vaccinate, but there is still a recommendation to vaccinate.  Administrative guidance was also added for further clarity on this population.

Version	3.3
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	Contraindication Text Description	Some Text Descriptions included a reference to Ty21a vaccine	Incorrect reference removed	Text Description inappropriately referred to a Typhoid vaccine.
Change	2	Risk Series Default Series Value	Yes	No	The concept of a Default Series is not appropriate for a risk series as selection of the best risk series is related to risk indications for the individual and Series Priority.
Change	3	Risk 1-dose series	Yes	CVX codes 183 and 184 added as Allowable Vaccines	New CVX codes created to account for the short-term import and use of Stamaril into the United States.

Version	3.2
Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change
Change	1	FAQ tab	N/A	FAQ tab added	FAQ tab created to answer frequently asked questions about the supporting data.

Change	Change #	Area	Previous	Change	Reason for Change

series:
Series Name	Yellow Fever risk 1-dose series
Target Disease	Yellow Fever
Vaccine Group	Yellow Fever
Administrative Guidance	Text
Administrative Guidance	A single primary dose of yellow fever vaccine provides long-lasting protection and is adequate for most travelers but additional doses of yellow fever vaccine are recommended for certain travelers with ongoing risk.
Administrative Guidance	Women who were pregnant (regardless of trimester) when they received their initial dose of yellow fever vaccine should receive 1 additional dose of yellow fever vaccine
Administrative Guidance	Persons who received a hematopoietic stem cell transplant after receiving a dose of yellow fever vaccine and who are sufficiently immunocompetent to be safely vaccinated should be revaccinated
Administrative Guidance	A booster dose may be given to travelers who received their last dose of yellow fever vaccine at least 10 years previously and who will be in a higher-risk setting based on season, location, activities, and duration of their travel
Administrative Guidance	Persons who were infected with HIV when they received their last dose of yellow fever vaccine should receive a dose every 10 years if they continue to be at risk for yellow fever virus infection.
